145211897.review:
[h1][b]The go-to default for moe lovers?[/b][/h1]
I am no stranger to the name [i]Yuzusoft[/i], and certainly, this is not my first review of a game by said company either. However, among all the titles I have previously played, Senren＊Banka is the only romance visual novel that manages to catch the attention of the mainstream.

Question: What makes this game the gateway for many foreign fans to the [i]Yuzusoft[/i] brand? This is a question I aim to answer in this review.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Info[/h2]
Senren＊Banka is the 9th title developed by [i]Yuzusoft[/i] in 2016 and was later brought to Steam by [i]NekoNyan[/i] and [i]HIKARI FIELD[/i] in 2020. 

[table][tr][th]Category[/th][th]Description[/th][/tr][tr][td]Language[/td][td]English, Simplified Chinese, Traditional Chinese, and Japanese[/td][/tr][tr][td]R18 content[/td][td]None, R18 patch is required for access[/td][/tr][/table]


[h2]Production Value[/h2]
[i]Yuzusoft[/i] never disappoints when it comes to presentation. This is especially the case for Senren＊Banka, thanks to its Japanese mythology roots. Hoori is a fictional town that is brimming with cultural integrities. "Historical" is the norm: from old architecture to the traditional garments, shamisen strumming in the background. It has a clear distinct identity that stands out from the rest.

Oh my, to my surprise, the music takes a step even further in nailing the theme of the game close to perfection. Words alone simply cannot describe the beauty of Hoori without mentioning the soundtrack. To further illustrate, it is a modern take on traditional Japanese music, and I highly recommend listening to it in lossless format. Of course, voice acting is superb too (if you are wondering).

[table][tr][th]Category[/th][th]Result[/th][th]Verdict[/th][/tr][tr][td]Resolution[/td][td]1080p[/td][td]🟩[/td][/tr][tr][td]Refresh Rate[/td][td]Native[/td][td]🟩[/td][/tr][tr][td]Framerate[/td][td]Unlocked[/td][td]🟩[/td][/tr][tr][td]Bugs / Issues[/td][td]None[/td][td]🟩[/td][/tr][/table]


[h2]Story[/h2]
Two words: poor pacing. Senren＊Banka is a game that is slow to pick up its momentum whenever necessary, fast to end its highlights for no good reason. More often than not, it severely breaks the flow of the storytelling.

For a game about Japanese folklore, the contents on display are often stretched thin to make room for more slice-of-life and comedy elements, resulting in the story lacking any conciseness in its narrative. To be clear, I do not dislike such elements being included in a visual novel (in fact, I am a big fan of it), as it helps to establish the characters, giving readers a reason to care for them. However, there exists a delicate balance in deciding when and how to incorporate these elements into the narrative. Unfortunately, Senren＊Banka struggles to find that middle ground.

On the flip side, you do get a cast of likeable characters that are, of course, carefully written to represent a certain archetype to distinguish themselves. Comedy, for the most part, is entertaining (albeit cliché) and the heroines are even more so lovable. At the very least, it hits all the right checkmarks (as a romance visual novel) with their target audience.

To summarise, if story is the least of your concerns, by all means, just go for it. Otherwise, the issues I mentioned above are carried over to the heroine routes as well. It can, at times, feel like fillers after fillers, with the story moving at a snail's pace.


[u][b]Yoshino:[/b][/u]
I don’t hate it, but I expected more. Especially, after revolving the entire plot around her in the Common route. It is a bit unfortunate that the route ultimately did not provide much closure to the main story itself.

Precisely because the Common route had already reached its conclusion, there isn't much left on the table for content. Still, I would not consider this as a bad route. Underwhelming? Maybe, but not bad. For the most part, the theme of personal growth is the centrepiece of the storytelling. It demands Yoshino to come out of her shell and face her own set of obstacles along the way.

Romance is great. I do enjoy the chemistry between Yoshino and Masaomi. It can be silly at times, due to how socially awkward Yoshino is in expressing herself. It helps to establish that romantic relationship between the two.

Of course, you do get a series of climaxes near the end, in which (finally) the main storyline has once again shown its relevance, tying in with the theme of the route.


[u][b]Murasame:[/b][/u]
One of the things I liked about this route was its heavy involvement with the other cast members. It recaptures the essence of the Common route, as an extension to the main story itself. Displaying the aftermath of the Common route in full.

Simultaneously, it also taps into Murasame's own mental fortitude as the only non-human heroine. A being who has outlived others for many generations is bound to have a backstory to tell and a fair amount of regrets to share.

If I haven't made my point clear by now, protect that smile at all cost! Especially the ending, making it all the more worthwhile. Also yes, Murasame is the best girl.


[u][b]Mako:[/b][/u]
I will say this upfront, it is a mess. Honestly, I lost count of the amount of times I wanted to give up on reading this. "Why" you may ask. Same deal as the criticism I mentioned before, but amplified.

Mako's route suffers the most (when compared) in terms of its pacing. Everything just feels unbearably slow, with seemingly nothing in between. Plotwise, it is also barebones at best, with zero urgency throughout.

There were some funny and heartwarming moments, but "is it justified enough to bear with the cons" is a question I am constantly asking myself. Just to be clear, Mako is not a bad heroine. But, the way how the game handles her character arc is just outright insulting.


[u][b]Lena:[/b][/u]
First and foremost, the game falls short in introducing Lena to the readers during the Common route. She is consistently neglected as a heroine, maintaining very little presence throughout.

Predictably, based on Steam achievements, not many have cleared her route. I wasn’t even sure what to expect either. However, as I delved deeper, it became evident that this was the spark the story desperately needed.

It offers a whole new dimension of questions to the main plot itself. Creating fresh and new story content that was not possible before. Dare I say, the final missing chapter to conclude the story. Super underrated, in my opinion. Not to mention, it also avoids over-centralising the focus to only Lena, giving others the opportunity to shine as well.

Romance, on the other hand... Masaomi, what happened to you? No matter how assertive Lena is with her approach, my guy is not able to read between the lines. For whatever reason, he became denser than a rock, and I blame the writers for that. It can, at times, feel irritating, to say the least.


[u][b]Koharu & Roka:[/b][/u]
As a side route (dateable supporting characters), the story is self-contained without overstaying its welcome. A short and enjoyable experience. Featuring both Koharu and Roka as heroines also allows for twice the romantic interaction with our main protagonist, as a contest of love.

As expected, the route ends with a choice between the two. Maybe they could, you know, make a third alternate ending... [i]wink[/i]


[h2]Verdict [u](7.5/10)[/u][/h2]
The reasons behind the numerous praises that Senren＊Banka has garnered are evident, thanks to its distinctive setting and remarkably high production value. It is a well-made product that anyone can at least appreciate. Especially when you factor in its low price and frequent discounts. Without a doubt, an easy thumbs up for my recommendation.

144025449.review:
In attempting to beat all Overwhelmingly Positive games on steam I gave this:

Game-play: ★☆☆☆☆ (Minimal)
Aesthetics: ★★★★☆ (Great)
Story: ★★★☆☆ (Decent)
Difficulty: ☆☆☆☆☆ (None)
Length: ★★★★☆ (Long)
Overall: ★★★☆☆ (Neutral)

★★★ Overview ★★★
Senren Banka is an interactive visual novel set in the fictional town of Hoori, Japan. You play as Masaomi, a late teen boy who visits the town to help his grandfather run a busy inn, and ends up getting mixed up in a local folk legend involving a magical katana, cursed spirits, and the Yoshino family's legacy of attempting to dispel the grudge that has haunted the town for hundreds of years. Through the process of dealing with the legend, the main character ends up falling in love with one of 6 different girls. 

The game is essentially broken up into two sections, the common route (chapters 1-3), and then the individual routes (chapters 4-8). The common route mostly deals with the cursed spirits harassing the town and resolving the curse. In each of the individual routes, the feel of the game changes quite a lot from an action-mystery setting, to more of a slice of life dating sim. 

★★★ Rating explanations and personal thoughts ★★★
★ Game-play: Being a visual novel there isn't really much to talk about game-play wise. Some decisions you make can affect the ending you receive, so there is at least some minor engagement, but there wasn't any particular time I felt like I recognized myself having fun. 
★ Aesthetics: The aesthetics were quite good, the art was exceptional, the voice acting was anime quality, and the sound and ambiance were appropriate. There was even a few anime-quality cut-scenes that were fully animated. 
★ Story: The story was pretty "meh" overall. Interesting during the common route, but each girls' individual routes were completely hit or miss. There was nothing revolutionary about the story, but it held my attention long enough to want to complete all possible routes. I hated Lena during the common route, but her individual route ended up being my favorite overall. I liked Mako and Murasame in the common route, and then disliked them more in their individual routes. It was somewhat jarring to have my opinion changed on basically every character throughout the full context of the story. 
★ Difficulty: It's a visual novel, there is no difficulty.
★ Length: It took 10 hours to finish the common route, and 10 hours to finish my first ending (Mako), so 20 hours to get to the credits once, it took 70 hours total to finish all endings. 

★ Overall: I think this is probably one of the better visual novels out there. It does everything well, but nothing in particular was mind blowing. Probably a must play for people who enjoy games like this in general, but not something I would just recommend to anyone.

143783606.review:
Senren * Banka is an interesting case in the visual novel space for how to do things well, yet also how to do things badly. The experience within is well worth the price of admission if you're looking for a good storyline in an interesting setting accented by a beautiful aesthetic, but you're going to be sorely disappointed if you come for the characters or the romance.

The common route of this piece is a full arc in its own right. It follows Arichi Masaomi as he assists the shrine maiden of Hoori, Tomotake Yoshino, and her ninja companion, Hitachi Mako, in solving the mystery of the curse casted upon Hoori and attempting to resolve it. It's a neat storyline that progresses at a good pace, then ends in a good spot before branching off into the various character routes. This part of the story is, for the most part, well done. The setting and the conflict fit together well and it's entirely believable that the solution that is used to resolve it isn't discovered before the time of the main story.

The strength of the story carries on through to the routes. Discounting the sub-routes of Roka and Koharu, the other four routes each carry a significant piece of the puzzle regarding how the curse came about and its full nature. I'm a big fan of this type of storytelling in Visual Novels since it grounds the entire story together to be a compelling whole rather than a jumbled set of individual arcs. My one complaint, which is generally a consistent one across this style, is that there is a near required order to the routes that will lessen the impact of the individual routes if you do not follow it. The generally accepted route order that I usually see is Yoshino -> Mako -> Murasame -> Lena, but I strongly believe that doing Murasame's route last is much better for the overall arc of the story, even if it doesn't have the best climax at the end. It's ultimately whichever you prefer for whichever route order you would enjoy more.

The art and music are definitely above average. The characters and set pieces are vibrant and do a great job of setting the right atmosphere for the entirety of the piece. Murasame in particular has a design that directly shows how much effort went into setting the right atmosphere for the story. The voice acting is consistently high quality as well, even among the side characters. Lena and Genjuurou are the two performances that I was particularly impressed by, since their characters felt like the most difficult to properly pull off for how well the performances were nailed. The music isn't top notch by any means, but it was clear that care went into the composition. These two together would comprise around a 7/10 in my eyes; definitely good enough to be worthy of praise, but not so good as to be memorable for months afterwards.

Finally, let's get to the worse parts of Senren * Banka.

While the setting and the story are quite good, the characters are the most glaring weak link. The main character is a jumbled mess, having a very lackluster backstory that doesn't match his personality or actions throughout the story. Each of the heroines have very generic personalities throughout the common route that range from minimal to decent characterization in their routes. Murasame's route features the most characterization of every route, while the other three primary heroines get essentially generic or minimal changes. The characters simply do not make the routes work the way you would hope in a romance story. As a plus, however, the side characters are quite well characterized, which is bizarre since it's rare for them to have a depth of personality when it doesn't feel like the primary characters do.

Speaking of romance, it's very lackluster. This is likely because the characters involved are so weak, but the romance in every single route (including the sub routes) are essentially retreads of the same thing. You're getting the same flowery generic romance story six different times with the differences coming down to the individual way the overall story affects that particular arc. It feels very forced and that they didn't even want to create a romance story in the first place, or that the developers fleshed out the overall storyline of this piece and just shoved romance in to appeal to the masses on release. 

In conclusion, Senren * Banka joins the extensive list of Visual Novels that had a lot of potential out of the gate, but simply fall short in an important way. I don't regret buying and playing through this game, and its clear that there was a lot of effort put into it, but this is an experience of driving through a beautiful landscape on a terribly maintained road. Enjoy the aesthetic and the story, but keep in mind that there is a price to pay to experience it.

---

I play Visual Novels for its characterization and storytelling potential. If you are interested in the medium for these reasons, visit my profile for more information. This includes more reviews and a link to my vndb profile, where I have ratings and TL;DRs of every Visual Novel I have played. Thank you.

143180332.review:
[b]DISCLAIMER:[/b] I haven't actually 100% the game yet.

A short description of Senren * Banka would be [u]"a wholesome eroge"[/u]. If by that you are intrigued then you should see it for yourself. In this review I'll talk about the setting, cast and specially the gameplay, but I won't actually spoil any story details. If you don't want to know how many options you actually have in the game, stop reading right now.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]The actual review[/h1]

Senren * Banka is a simplistic visual novel, with a simplistic storyline, simplistic characters and simplistic decisions. This does not make the game bad but it doesn't make it that special either. Actually, calling this game a visual novel could be misleading, because you really don't have that many options. Yes, you have different endings and routes, but it's not like other heavy visual novel titles in which you need to make a lot of decisions and explore different scenarios until you reach the end.

This could be almost cataloged as a kinetic novel. The choices are straightforward and you can get into the route of the girl you most want without any issues. For me, this is a turnoff. Altought I really hate when novels make stupid requirements for reaching X or Y ending, I also hate when it's so basic that it makes you wonder why they added them in the first place.

This VN has some good ideas like a Flowchart, saving dialogue lines & so on while also not really using them to the fullest potential. Like, why would I need a Flowchart for my decisions if they don't actually matter in the big scheme of things?

Yes, it's hard to make a branching storyline for a game this long but that does not mean you need to bait me like that. I was expecting much more when I saw just how many options you had at your disposal. However this decision makes sense when you see what the team behind Senren * Banka tried to make.

[h1]Story & Characters[/h1]

[u]Might spoil some minor details about the story.[/u]

This game is an eroge. The 'heroines' are basically models with explendid bodies and their personalities are just too pure for this world. [spoiler]All of them are virings who want to experience love, real love, and you are the one to give them that.[/spoiler] You also have your all-time favorite cliches like your childhood friend which you haven't seen for a while, your big sister, your 500 year old loli, the princess that is kind but really cold, the servant of that princess that's wife material but doesn't realize it, and your airheaded friend that just too nice to everyone.

Senren * Banka is not reinventing the wheel. Althought the story is fairly original the characters are not and you have seen someone similar somewhere else, specially if you played a lot of VNs & you consumed a lot of manga/anime. Again, this does not make the story or characters bad, but rather expected. It's not boring but you get what you see. They will fall for you the same way you expect.

Don't forget this is an eroge. The MC will sometimes have the luck of Rito from To LOVE-Ru. All the tropes from that series are going to happen in some way or another. This does not make the game less wholesome tho. Even if characters have sexual desires they are kept in check while somewhat still being wholesome. They tend to find their own sexuality and desires in such a pure way that it seems wrong seeing them do it tbh.

[spoiler]This game has no drama at all, no love-triangles, no actual fights between characters. I was expecting some kind of drama but I did not find it here.[/spoiler]

[h1]Gameplay & Settings[/h1]

As stated before, this game is far closer to a kinetic novel than an actual visual novel with branching stories. You have decision making but its more like "hey you want to end with girl A or girl B?". Moreover, I think you have a bigger number of decisions in the H! scenes than the others. Those scenes are kinda pointless and if you don't have the R18 patch I think you can't see them. Yes, the game has a patch but to be completely honest I ended up skipping all those H! scenes because I felt bad watching them. For context, I played "Monster Girl Club Bifrost" patched without any issue. The problem for me here is that is like I was watching two lovers have sex, like it's something I shouldn't be seeing.

The game has some nice features. You have a "panic button" that changes whatever you are seeing in game for a photo of your liking, for the folks that don't have any privacy. You also have a lot of options in the configuration menu. I'm a fan of configuration options. I like games to be as configurable as possible. Sometimes is hard for developers to implement these kind of features, but that's mainly because of desing and not because they are actually hard to implement.

You can set the voice of all characters, you can hide some UI elements, you can even change the text size, font and color. The only thing really lacking is the auto-mode because it works like ass, maybe because no one uses it (apart from me T . T). The auto-mode will NOT take into consideration long texts so you will eventually need to pause the game and go back.

There aren't that many effects in the game. Other VNs will play a lot more with the text box. Senren * Banka text box in comparison is too simplistic. This is a minor nit-pick but, for VNs, using the text box in creative ways is a plus and it always amazes me when some developer is creative with it. Just think of Doki Doki Literature Club!. Heck, this VN cant even make pauses between the same text box dialogue so you kinda get spoiled on what the character is going to say next.

[h1]Music & Voice Acting[/h1]

Senren * Banka has actual voice acting for all characters except the MC. That's really cool. Sometimes I find myself waiting for the voice line to finish before pressing space, because I actually want to hear the VA say something silly.

And the music is alright. I have the main theme stuck in my head but that's about it. I'll certainly forget it after a few weeks.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Overall[/h1]

This is a nice, wholesome game, at least for Japanese media standards. Yes, there is ecchi and xxx scenes, but it's still between two loving and consenting adults. This is not a porn game or some fap material, it's just a wholesome story. Yes, it has a lot of cliches and thropes, and yes the characters are unrealistic and just too pure, kinda shallow, but that's actually what they were trying to achieve with this.

Sometimes reading a VN like this is just fine. Ofc I would be bored if all VNs were like this, so maybe I won't play anything from this game-studio ever again, but that does not mean this is a bad game.

Just check it out. If you are still bored after the common route is completed (from 4-8 hours) then it's probably not for you.

136193301.review:
First off I want to say this game is more buggy than Windows ME. This game crashed so many times on me, it was always when a video was going to start and i would literally have to spam save all the up to before the video and then just keep reloading the game until it decided to play and not crash, I am talking 5-10 attempts. Multiply this with 6 stories and it was frustrating and took the impact out of the end of the stories when it would fade to credit and then crash to desktop. Nothing in the forums about it so maybe it was just my PC.

 As for the story. It's hit and miss. The common route sets up a excellent story which Murasame's route wraps up great, and just rating the story based off what I considered to be cannon and the story is a solid 9 and should be read for her route alone. 

But the issue is I knew Murasame was the cannon story so I did her route last (As should you.) The other stories I can't be super nice with. Senren Banka is a painfully slow read and when 3 routes are pretty much the same from a different perspective, one route is unique but splits into the worst route, the slow read really shows it's head.  This story just takes it sweet time getting anywhere, so when you're reading a scene that is similar, but different to another route, it's easy to start glazing over. 

I don't want to ruin anything so I am going to just rate each route in the order that I did them.

Mako (7.5) - Started strong with a good personal conflict but it was easily and quickly gotten over and turned into probably the most sexual story? But at the same it's actually pretty funny what goes on in it. The story gives you a follow up to the history. It worked for me as a first route, but it would had been better as a second route since the lore was more about "motivation," while Lena's was about the straight scoop. But Mako was the girl I wanted to date first. Who doesn't want a pervy hot Ninja that reads manga?

Lena (8) - Probably the best route next to Murasame, I liked Lena, she was funny and this route is a huge context dump, it explains the entire history. (I recommend this as the first route) and honestly I felt this had the 2nd best ending behind Murasame.

Roka/Koharu - This is where the slow pacing starts to take it's toll, neither of these girls have shit to do with the main story and were not in the common route very often so this route turns everything into a completely new story. These stories are 100% slice of life and ditches the supernatural element.

Roka (8) - I really enjoyed the change of pace and her story was excellent. Nothing was recycled and it was a nice read. 

Koharu (1) - Why? Why the hell was this a option? Was this a crowdfunding milestone or something? Not only does this route choice happen in the MIDDLE of Roka's story and it ditches it all together. it is the most eye rolling, boring ass story. I almost wrote a negative review after wrapping this route up.  [spoiler] She is the MC cousin, they are having sex and want to date, will the MC's family and friends approve of this? [/spoiler] <--- Yes that one black mark is the entire story, that's how dumb it is. The only saving grace is it's short, because of course it is. Koharu is literally for people who want a loli H-scene.

Yoshino (7.5) Ok we are back to the main story. I was expecting a little more from Yoshino, but since Mako and Lena gives the context dump there isn't much new addition to the lore. But Yoshino is so damn cute so i didn't mind. Her personal story and conflicts felt the most fleshed out, right behind Murasame.

Murasame (9) The cannon story as I mentioned. Also the longest. I won't say anything else.

The music and acting is really good, the backgrounds are nice and the models are a little basic but good enough.

OK, let's talk H-scenes. I actually don't really like H-scenes in these kind of stories, I do add the patch and the entire time a H-scene plays I sit there debating if I should just uninstall it as I put on headphones and try to speed up the conversation while making sure not to miss any important character development. Overall I feel they just threw them in last minute, because it becomes predictable when one was about to happen.  But don't listen to me on H-scenes since I am biased, I feel they cheapen a good romance and it's hard to hear the MC talk all lovey dubby after giving a girl a facial after she performed oral sex in a public space. Don't ask me why I always install the patches, I just do. 

This was story definitely not on the same level a Kinkoi: Golden Loveriche which just had more interesting story routes and much better character art (Subjective) but this story is worth it for Murasame's route alone

I recommend this. But unless you want all the achievements, skip Koharu and expect a super slow read, take breaks. I am a moderate to slow reader that turns auto read to about 45% speed.

135670901.review:
This is the first visual novel/eroge I've finished to the end. I've been trying to expose myself to these titles for quite some time now to understand the appeal behind them since I enjoy exploring various gaming categories. As of the time of this review, I've come to understand a lot more so it's only fitting I place my impression in this review. 

First and foremost, Yuzusoft is amazing and they deserve all the love that they get with their games. I've tried penetrating the VN genre with surface recommendations from web searches and a lot of them are plagued with bad hardware support and modern features that games from other genres have been using for years. 
I'm really impressed at the progress the studio have made with the development of their game engine. The interface is clean, software has zero performance hiccups, key binds are convenient, and accessibility features are there. You can also see them constantly improving the experience with their newer titles. 

On top of that, all of the dialogues are fully voiced and the art is phenomenal in seemingly all of their games. With all that said, the only thing left to discuss is the narrative. 

At first, I thought that the narrative for Senren Banka is a little lackluster. It's not bad but it's also nothing noteworthy. I mostly found the long aimless slice-of-life sections in the game to be boring. I thought it was out of place and wasted a lot of my time. 
However, later I realized that it's a deliberate decision by the writer. The appeal of these games, and why they work, is the parasocial relationship that they provide. They need to prioritize the experience you have with the character you chose in your route. That way, the NSFW sections are more compelling. I used to generalize the VNs in one category but it seems like their lewd/dating iterations should be judged entirely different.

With that in mind, I would say Senren Banka has a very good narrative. I found the legends behind Hoori to be intriguing and I enjoyed all of the little plot points they have made in conjunction to it. While I would've enjoyed it if they had a stronger narrative to surround the world building they have, balancing it alongside the slice-of-life sections would result into a longer game which would not really be ideal.

I highly recommend this game for people getting into the eroges.

133983619.review:
[h1]-This is more translation review than a review about the game itself-[/h1]
[quote][i]I'm not really sure if I should give positive or negative review. There's no option for in-between.[/i][/quote]

Senren Banka is an amazing VN, after playing Sanobawitch a few years ago I instantly bought this on its launch day. And yes, the story is amazing, although at the time I writing this review (2023-03-03) I have only play 3 out of 4 main route (Mako, Murasame & Lena), and side stories haven't been touched.
You know I'm glad the title is translated by NekoNyan instead of SP. But I have set my expectation way too high, while the translation is not as fully cringe as SP, I can't help but feel a little disappointed. I drop this a few times, and then back playing it again, over and over again. I'm not sure if I want to continue the rest of the story because of the translation. It's that kind of feeling where I'm still curious about story and I want to see it more and play it again and then when I see the translation, ugh, I can't, I wish I could forget what I see. Yes I am that kind of guy who picky about translation. There was times when I use Textractor and machine-translate it myself directly from Japanese text, but it's not really convenient and it crash or failed sometimes.

So what make me hate the translation?
[list][*]The first one is, SP style when joke/wordplay "converted" (not translated) into western joke. VN are niche game, hardly any normies play this, no need to change Japanese joke or meme into what they think as a western equivalent of the joke, pretty sure majority of the player already understand and familiar with Japanese joke & meme anyway. For example "Chotto matta!" translated to "Stop right there criminal scum!". That's cringe. Also everyone already know who it is, no one force you to translate "Roboneko" as "Doraemon". And there are more stuff like that.
[*]And the second one is inconsistency, a lot of it. For example 竹刀 doesn't even have consistent translation as sometimes translated as "bamboo sword", "wooden sword", and sometimes simply as "shinai". And the second one is much more important because it's a character name: 白狛, where in name section it's translated as "White Komainu", but in dialogue it's "Shirokoma". If you have good memory, actually listen to dialogue and read the text, you will notice more things like this.[/list]

But other than that, there are also good things that I like from NN translation:
[list][*]Original Japanese name order, they are still "FamilyName GivenName".
[*]Original honorific included, they still write -chan, -san, etc. at almost all of them.
[*]Using original measurement, they didn't convert it into feet when the dialogue mention it in meter, and also still translating floor originally but with added explanation instead of straight convert it into meter/feet.[/list]
Although I have mixed feeling about their choice to leave the princess title not translated.


So what's my opinion about this game?
Game & story: ★★★★★ (only 3 out 4 routes finished so far)
Translation: ★★☆☆☆
I'm not really sure if I should give positive or negative review. There's no option for in between. I wish there's more than Yes or No in Steam review, better if there's separate points for gameplay, bgm, story, etc..

132794959.review:
Could be better, could be worse.

I gotta say that I like the production quality: The UI is great, art is well-made, soundtrack fits well, the voice acting is almost flawless and translation is perfect. It all just looks and feels good. The free and easy to add extra content patch is also nice. At first everything about this VN looks really good.

But there are a few flaws that are worth mentioning. For example, the story. It all seems promising at first. The town of Hoori feels alive and it's traditions play a big part in the story. And up to individual girl paths there isn't a lot to nitpick. However it's only a small part of the story and only makes up like 20% at most and everything after that slowly goes downhill. The first individual route might seem nice, they have a decent plot to them, but every route shares a lot in common. Some events (like canceling an important engagement) definitely happens in at least 4 of the routes, but is only really described in detail in a single one. Not really a bad thing but it is an example of big similarities in the different routes. After some time you start to make connections and after some more time you can kinda guess when major plot twits are gonna happen. And some routes are clearly better. For example Hitachi's route had her own special scenes in the main route and an unexpected story, a big existential struggle, a hobby (something that other girls lacked), an interesting personality, the best h-scenes, and the most interesting story. And it's not a biased opinion, it's fact. Instead like how it is in other story rich VNs, here every ending felt weaker that the previous one. And there wasn't a true ending! I understand that it might be hard to to connect the 7 (or 8) different routes, but not having a final ending just leaves an unpleasant aftertaste you get from the last remaining bad and boring endings. Finishing the last route didn't even give a sense of accomplishment or anything. Oh and the After stories that take place some time after the main story finished. Like 2 or 3 of them really feel needed and in reality all of em are just additional h-scenes. And I gotta say those scenes are kinda lame. Lame as in too vanilla. Out of 20+ scenes that are in the novel, all of it is either a titjob, blowjob or just vanilla action (besides that one foot job with Yoshino). It all is just aimed for the general audience and as a result it's not special. I would have probably enjoyed it more if I had played it as an absolute visual novel beginner.

Nothing really stands out and it all just passes.

It was still fun so I still really recommend it.

129037266.review:
[h1]I'm a ninja, after all, this is a piece of cake, fufu[/h1]
[h1]Story[/h1]
In the deep parts of the mountains lies a small village called [b]Hoori[/b], a remote village with no train stops. Thanks to this isolation, the village has resisted the spread of civilization, giving it a rustic charm, and is also home to hot springs. This has led it to be a very famous tourist destination for people to travel to, but its most famous attraction is the divine blade [b]Murasamemaru[/b]. This blade has been stuck in a stone though and so far, no one has ever been able to pull it out.

[b]Arichi Masaomi[/b] is visiting the village to help his grandfather run a hotel he manages, and he happens to try and pull the blade out, which he successfully does. At the cost of breaking the blade and now, he must make amends for what he has done. How may you ask? Well by marrying the village’s shrine maiden of course. This is only the start for [b]Arichi[/b], as he has to come to terms with everything that is happening at this time, his time at [b]Hoori[/b], will certainly be a wild ride.

Although that is not all that is there in [b]Hoori[/b] village, as on some nights, demons will come out into the forest thanks to the [b]Tomotake[/b] curse. [b]Yoshino Tomotake[/b] and [b]Mako Hitachi[/b] must purify the demons when they come out to subdue the curse as a whole. The two tell [b]Masaomi[/b] to sit it out but he does not want that and decides to help out and get stronger as a whole. Thanks to his grandpa [b]Kurama Genjuurou[/b] running a dojo, he can get stronger and help fight demons with the help of the sword [b]Murasame[/b], who happens to have a green-haired ghost attached to it that is afraid of other ghosts despite being one herself.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Interesting story with plenty of fun characters
[*]Five different routes with seven unique endings
[*]Wonderful music that is very pleasing to listen to
[*]Beautiful art style that makes each area full of life and shines
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Masaomi is generic and lacks character development
[*]Some of the fan service content is a little unnecessary
[*]The pace of the story can be a bit slow at times
[/list]

[h1]Characters[/h1]
[b]Senran Banka[/b] has a wonderful cast of characters, and the story is interesting to boot as well. One of my favorite aspects is the whole mythological aspects of the story. I wish it was explored more throughout the story, as I think it would have been a neat idea as a whole to explore. Although when it is talked about, that's when I get very invested in the story, with a unique premise and with it even having its own history felt very [b]Japanese Mythology[/b] like. [b]Senran Banka[/b] is spread apart into two sections for its story, the first one is where you are dealing with and exploring the mythological aspect that it has. The other part is the character development for the route you have chosen to do.

There are a total of five different routes for you to experience, with seven different endings and scenarios. I chose the [b]Mako[/b] route as [b]Mako[/b] was a ninja and ninjas are cool~. I enjoyed her personality the most out of all the characters. She helps the [b]Tomotake[/b] family out with the housework and the hunting of demons on certain nights. The other character that I liked was [b]Roka Maniwa[/b], she runs a sweet shop and I actually think she is the best-designed character besides [b]Mako[/b]. If it were not for [b]Mako[/b], I probably would have chosen [b]Roka's[/b] route, although I do wish she had more screen time as a whole and maybe played a larger role in the story.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2905036817
Just a note, there is also an option for you to date your cousin, but you can easily avoid that route if this sort of thing bothers you.

Now, with all that positivity, comes a few issues that [b]Senran Banka[/b] suffers from, and while it does not hold it back, they are still worth noting. [b]Masaomi[/b] plays out like a typically unlikeable main character with no personality. I do not like him, period, he is bland, boring, and just unlikeable. Since this is a dialog-heavy visual novel, this is a huge problem, as you want to make the main character at least likable as a whole.

The next issue I have is a combination of two issues. The fan service on occasion can be a little unnecessary in the story, even though I understand the use in some situations to better showcase certain aspects of specific characters. Now, this is fine on certain occasions, however, there are ways for you to make a character likable without a fan service scene. I did not like [b]Mako[/b] because of the fan service stuff, I liked [b]Mako[/b] because she was a Ninja and had the most interesting personality out of the bunch.

Since there is a little too much fanservice at times, this also slows the pacing down as well and it can be a bit of a slog to get through. I also hate the stereotype trope of every female character thinking that the MC is a pervert when he is really not. While [b]Senran Banka[/b] does not have all the typical anime tropes that are out there, it does have a few of them, that being, the worst ones imaginable.

[h1]Artstyle/Music[/h1]
The art style used in [b]Senran Banka[/b] is honesty really beautiful and very colorful in its areas shown. Each area is full of life and is very detailed, the character sprites are also very well done and definitely fit the art style that the visual novel was going for. I even like the designs that the demons had as well, they felt very mysterious while having a threatening charm to them that I liked.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2905036875
I'll take a moment to talk a bit about the music, as it’s definitely well done and deserving of its praise. The voice acting has to be another thing worth mentioning as I liked all the voices that the visual novel had to offer, there was never a voice I hated.

[h1]Performance[/h1]
I tested this VN on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM. I experienced no issues while I was playing, and it should be able to run on any computer.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
All in All, [b]Senran Banka[/b] is a visual novel worth your time and attention if you enjoy the slice-of-life type of stuff. It has a total of 50+ hours in terms of content, so if you are someone who likes to explore all possible situations, then I recommend this visual novel at full price. Although if you only plan to play this visual novel once, then you are better off getting it on sale, as 39.99 is definitely a steep price to pay for a 12-hour experience.

128831471.review:
This VN will be one of the last "slice of life (with a bit of action)" that I will ever play. 

It suffers from what they all do. Several routes that are all extremely similar, except when it comes to quality. One route clearly shines above all the others and a couple felt very rushed. They should've just stuck to the one well written character route and invested more into it and made that the entire VN. The routes are all full of cliches and tropes. 

The WORST part is how incredibly vanilla the H scenes are. No animations, all oral and standard penetration, and only 2 additions of flavor (golden nectar and an employed foot) in ONE of the character routes. These VNs are written to have mass appeal I guess, but I got bored so I skipped all but a few scenes. Surely anyone could skip something they don't like.

Now why do I recommend it despite my shade? Well the issue is mostly fatigue from several titles. There are many VNs (some without any adult stuff at all) that are truly well written, interesting, funny, niche/fetish, and/or explore something fascinating (STEINS:GATE, Doki Doki Lit. Club, Fata Morgana, Atri, Iwaihime, and even Nekopara, etc.).Senren Banka is not quite their pace or niche, it is mostly normal people doing normal things (with a supernatural twist to give them something to do other than eat pudding).

If this was my first slice of life/action/romcom VN, the tropes/cliches would be more endearing, the vanilla H would be hotter, and the samey routes would feel fresher and more distinct. There is certainly enough humor, quality writing, and art to warrant enjoying. 

I had a lot of fun overall, but the last 10-15 play hours I was mostly just wanting it to change pace or end.

120819070.review:
[u]Disclaimer:[/u] I have only finished Mako, Roka, and Koharu's routes. I will update my review once I have finished all the other routes. I played whilst listening to most voiced lines.

[h1]Introduction[/h1]

The game starts with a main common route. Once it ends, you can choose to finish the game on the route of one of the four main girls, or Roka/Koharu's common route (locked on first playthrough). If you choose to go down Roka/Koharu's common route, once this ends, you can choose once again to go down Roka or Koharu's specific routes. The length of the main common route is around 10 hours, with each route of the main girl taking another 10 hours. Roka and Koharu's common route takes around 6 hours, and their specific route each take around 3 hours.

[u][h1] General review [/h1][/u]
[h1] Story and script-writing [/h1]

The visual novel intertwines advancing the main storyline whilst promoting the relationship between the MC and the girl. Excellent pacing and content keeps you gripped on the main storyline whilst also keeping your heart throbbing for the interactions between the characters. The script-writing fully captures the charms of the character, and makes each scene feel vibrant and cohesive. It does an especially good job of capturing one of Yuzusoft's best qualities in their VNs: making the girls feel clingy. What I mean by this is that you can really see and feel how the girl falls more and more in love with the MC, with exceptional scenes and scripts along each step of their developing feelings.

[h1]Voice acting[/h1]

The game is fully voice acted save for the MC and narration. I believe this is the best combo as it helps immensely in the world-building whilst also not breaking any immersion. Each character is brought to life by VAs that capture the essence of their character, where emotions are conveyed wholly and impactfully.

[h1]H Content[/h1]

As with most VNs, the quality of the script drops substantially as soon as H content start. Superior to most VNs, despite this fact, it mostly remains a decent quality, with some pleasant surprises with good quality scripting. However, I did find myself fast reading some of the H content. H content is not included on Steam, you can download the patch on Yuzusoft's official website.

[h1]Sprite quality[/h1]

A very high number of poses and facial expressions are used on detailed sprites, which frequently changes during a conversation to keep the characters life-like and natural. Attention to detail is paid in order to get the perfect timing and sprite selection to achievement the aforementioned point, which makes it feel even more fluid than an animation.

[h1]CG quality (non H standpoint)[/h1]

There is a high number of CGs that are vibrant and dynamic. Overall quality is excellent, but it is emphasised by the outstanding timings the CGs are introduced. They serve to enhance the story and moments dramatically, and add to the fact that some details (e.g. facial expressions) can change whilst showing the CG, it serves as a powerful cornerstone for the VN to shine upon.

[h1]CG quality (H standpoint)[/h1]

Due to the nature of a H scene, it may sometimes feel repetitive because ultimately, it is still just one image. The H aspect is mostly decent, but sometimes it fails to successfully capture the balance between the H quality of the girl and the charm of the girl. That said, it still fully inherits all the good points discussed in the non-H standpoint, with the overall quality being better than most other VNs.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

You occasionally make choices that impact what route you end up going into (H-Scene choices have no impact).

[h1]Translation[/h1]

I played the game mostly in English and sometimes with Chinese sub-text. I can't speak for the faithfulness to the original (since I haven't seen the original), but both languages flow naturally and don't detract from the game's charm. There is no element of annoying over-localisation present, allowing you to fully enjoy the story.

[h1]Settings and misc[/h1]

The game excels in this aspect. Settings that are crucial for a VN, settings you may want in a VN, settings you didn't even think you will need in a VN, this has it all. Despite the high customizability, the settings are straight forward to navigate and comprehend, with the default being perfect acceptable as well. A small detail I really appreciate is that almost every navigation or options is accompanied by the voice of one of the girls. The game also features the ability to bookmark favourite voice lines, which is quite wonderful (I don't play a lot of VNs, so I'm not sure if this is a common feature). 

[h1]MC[/h1]

The game's MC does a good job of filling the role of a character in the world, whilst also not making it feel like you are watching a story from the sidelines. There is no eccentric qualities about him, which thankfully also means there are no annoying qualities about him. He is also not an emotionless insert; he is able to express various emotions appropriate for the scenario, so you won't find yourself cringing or raging over the MC's actions.

[u][h1]Routes[/h1][/u]
[u] Disclaimer: [/u] I may discuss what some may consider minor spoilers, but I promise there won't be any details pertaining to what happens. 

[h1]Common[/h1]

The common route is where you are introduced to the main storyline of the curse and the characters, whilst also building up the world of Hoori. The common route intertwines advancing the storyline of solving the curse whilst simultaneously showing off the personality of the characters and the charm of the girls. The former is achieved somewhat dully, with the majority coming from dialogue that feels dragging, but the latter is achieved phenomenally, from enticing dialogue sparkled with colourful CG, to well planned events that serve as a powerful backbone for the script to shine.

The proportion of the main story and dating aspect leans slightly towards the former, so I can't help but think that being a bit more skewed towards the latter, or at least being balanced, would making the common route more enjoyable. However, I'm no scriptwriter and I'm sure the currently balance has been tested and was deemed optimal. This is also more than made up by the fact that during a specific route, the dating aspect (even without considering H), is more pronounced than the main story (or in the case of Roka/Koharu, the main story completely ends).

World-building of Hoori is relatively simple, but that doesn't mean it feels one-dimensional. Details are sprinkled into the story to make the world believable and cohesive, and the balance between subtleness and explicitness leaves no room for confusion, whilst also not overwhelming you with details like a lorebook.

The actual story quality of the main plot (at least in the common route) is detailed, but unexciting. You can clearly see that whilst a detailed storyline is present, the heart of the VN is not here. Whilst you won't be bored or uninterested, you may start feeling indifferent about the events that happen in the main storyline.

The story quality of the dating aspect is where the positives of this VN shine through. You get a taste of each of the girls' charms, with enough details to understand their traits, and sufficient encouragement to select any of their routes. Each scene is carefully crafted to achieve this, with all elements of the VN working in harmony.

(Due to the character limit, I will be discussing each specific routes in the comments.)

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Whilst not the first VN I finished, as a relatively new VN player, this showed me the charms and potentials of VN. This VN was a brilliant introduction to the genre for me, and I can easily say its the best out of the limited number of ones I have played. For the current price, it is more than worth it, as the sheer quantity of quality content will easily be proven by the number of willing hours one would inevitably be putting in.

120367246.review:
A romance VN with a dash of Inuyasha? Sign me in!

[b] Note: [/b] due to recent findings, most of them being plot-related, I felt the need to re-review this game. The first time, I was more lenient towards this game. Not so much now.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

Senren *Banka is a romance VN developed by Yuzusoft. It has a heavy emphasis on the mystical elements of ancient Japan, and explores legends and stories from half a millenium ago. While in my original review didn't give the plot much thought, now I had, and, unfortunately, I found some glaring issues with it, and one of them is significant. On the upside, my character assesment will be largely unchanged.

[h1] Worldbuilding [/h1]

The game is set in current Japan, more specifically, in rural Japan, in the fictional town of Hoori. There are several mystical elements to take into account, like curses, guardian gods, legendary blades, spirits and so on. So, there is a lot of elements, so the rules governing them must be consistent with each other. Fortunately, the writers did their job properly, and I didn't found contradictive rules, or rules that don't make sense in the context they are introduced. Like I said earlier, most of the issues I found are related to the plot, and the worldbuilding elements were consistent, and they were good sources of conflict, tension and drama. So, nothing to complain about, on this regard at least.

[h1] The plot [/h1]

Oh, boy. The plot is about a group of teenagers fighting against a 500-year old curse. Like i said earlier, some of the elements of the plot reminded me of Inuyasha (in both the characters need to collect the shards of a relic). The main problem I have with this plot is the time passed since the curse was cast. I find it hard to swallow that no one, in 500 years, figured out a way to break the curse. Since the curse has dire ramifications for Hoori and its denizens, the fact that no one in half a millenium found any clue on how to break the curse, makes absolutely no sense. At the very least, I'd make the characters of the game figured things out using the clues found by other people before them. That way, this huge contrivance is turned into cause and effect. There also conveniences and inconveniences, and tone-deaf scenes that ruin serious character development moments. That said, the plot issues were more focused in the common route. The only issue I found in any of the heroines' routes was in Mako's, that could potentially change some elements of her plotline, but it's not too damaging.

[h1] The characters [/h1]

This is another strength of the game. This could probably the only romance VN where I liked all the heroines, with no exceptions. All of them has distinct personalities, quirks, flaws, desires, goals and motivations, some better than the other, but at least they are present. I think the strongest characters of this game, in terms of writing, are Yoshino and Murasame. The main character is decent, but he doesn't change much and his character development is barebones, the minimum necessary to be an actual character and not a tool for the writers to advance to plot. If only the writers had the same amount of effort writing the plot of this game, this could have been an absolute banger of a romance VN.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

As any branching VN, this game features choices that decides which heroine's route the player will end up. The difference with other games from the same developer, is the fact that it's possible to not raise any flags at all, which makes way more sense than how the other games function. I haven't tested raising the same amount of flags for each girl, so I can't say what'd happen. This game, unlike other romance VNs from other developers, features a flowchart, where the player can see the plot progression and the choices they made. It's a convenient way to track progress and to navigate through large portions of the plot without using functions like skip or backskip, or make another choice. The game also gives the option of recoloring read text, and it even lets the player customize the color to their liking. That's something I have never seen on other VNs, and I wish more developers do the same.

[h1] Artistic and technical elements [/h1]

This is the aspect in which Yuzusoft shines the brightest. Art direction, sound effects, voice acting, localization, all of that is top notch. The background and event CGs are superb, rich in detail, and shows the care of the illustrators for their craft. The voice acting is awesome, has emotional weight and shows the quality of Japanese voice acting. That said, I found some issues with dialogue, specifically in some Mako's lines, where the dialogue is out of order. This could be a localization issue or a voice direction issue, but it's a minor hiccup. The music is also on point, and it matches the tone and situation perfectly. The only real issue here is the performance in some instances. If you are using an iGPU or a budget graphics card to run this game, you could experience severe frame drops when two or more effects overlap each other. Even with my 3060 Ti I experienced some frame drops, so optimization is an issue here.

In conclusion:

[b] Pros: [/b]

-Solid worldbuilding.
-Well written characters.
-Good gameplay choices, with nice additions for good measure.
-Outstanding art direction, voice acting and other artistic elements.

[b] Cons: [/b]

-Nonsensical and awfully contrived main plot.
-Some optimization issues in key instances.

Though my view of this game is more critical than the first time, this game is still a good recommendation for people who like romance VNs. Less than before, but a recommendation nonetheless. Like I said in other review, I'm willing to overlook glaring plot issues if the characters are good. And this game delivers on that regard on spades.

120337975.review:
TL;DR the VN is decent, if somewhat generic. Be sure that you're the target audience (teenaged weebs) when playing. The trial mode is very representative of what you'll get and a great thing.

I haven't really played a lot of VNs before if JRPG segments don't count, but I thought I'd give it a try and this was the highest rated one around. I'm not really that into the anime tropes anymore and they're pretty ubiquitous here so that kind of hampered my enjoyment a bit but not to the point where I dropped it early. I'm writing this review after having played every route but Lena's.

[h1]Technical aspects[/h1]
The thing that made me buy this to try it out as opposed to simply pirating it was the options menu, funnily enough. The amount of complex customization you can do, from adjusting voice volume of specific characters to binding specific mouse gestures to customizing the color of already seen text, was honestly crazy to me.

Other than that, the game performed totally fine and I didn't notice any problems when playing outside of one somewhat problematic feature.

The auto mode. This feature is somewhat buggy, if you have the text speed at 100% you'll regularly find some unvoiced lines be skipped after voiced lines because of how this feature works. If you're on an unvoiced line of text when a voiced line stops, the unvoiced text is advanced in auto mode, this means that if the text is on the screen too quickly when the voice is less than a second from being done, that text will be skipped. Annoying. This can be fixed by setting text speed to 95%, it's still fast enough to be near indistinguishable.
The issue described above is a general flaw though, if you skip ahead in text and a voice line ends you'll sometimes skip unvoiced lines accidentally, although maybe I should've just stopped using auto mode at that point.

[h1]Production value[/h1]
This was somewhat saddening to me, after the options menu gave me such a good impression. The character images and backgrounds, as well as the music are all good, great even! But there's so little of it, the majority of the time you'll see the same character image with 2 outfits, about 7 different expressions and around 5 custom CGs (including sex scenes) per route. I had expected a few more custom images and was a little disappointed to find out that this is where they mainly saved on costs. Maybe I'm expecting too much of a 30$ game but then again, VNs don't have to care about gameplay at all, so I expect the funds to be put into things that are basically the "gameplay" of VNs.

On the other hand, the voice acting is top-notch and everything but the inner monologue and speech of the protagonist is voiced. No complaints here at all.

[h1]Plot and characters[/h1]
I'll write a bit about the character-specific routes without spoilers below my abstract thoughts on them, which come next.

The plot itself is alright, I was not particularly invested in it, but it didn't bore me to tears and was satisfactorily resolved in the basic route. It's definitely more of a vehicle for character interactions than anything else, outside of the character-specific routes.

The characters are pretty good actually, most of them are decently fleshed out by the time you've played all routes and have multiple motivations for their actions. They're not especially complex or deep, but they have enough going for them that you can emphasize and, in some cases, relate. 
Most of the character development of a character is locked behind a character-specific route though, during the basic route they remain rather static, which is fine because that's where you get to know them in the first place. Although, the relationships between the characters could've been expanded upon, it sometimes feels like characters cease to exist if the protagonist doesn't interact with them.

Two final things to note, despite what the game may say, these characters are not 18+ and certainly don't act anywhere near that age. The main character is a very vexing person in the basic route, and only really seems to grow out of his macho phase once you start the character-specific routes. Outside those moments, he's a very passive and "nice" person, probably for ideal self-insertion. Although, he's made dense to the point of self-delusion in some routes.
Furthermore, basically every heroine turns into a blushing innocent lily the moment they're romanced, I suppose this may be a more cultural thing about the Japanese female ideal, but it's noticeable where one second they're confident in themselves and the next they're a blushing stuttering wreck that has never dated anybody. I suppose they didn't want to give an impression of "used goods" which in of itself is a pretty toxic view. In one of the routes a heroine mentions that she's happy the protagonist has never dated somebody either because she didn't want to feel like she'd be compared to a prior experience, which is understandable if a rather immature view.

Time for a spoiler free overview of the character-specific routes, I'll mainly split it up between the romance/relationship and the plot of the route. The number next to their name is the age based on maturity I'd assign the heroine and protagonist in this route. The order is the way I played them in.

Murasame(19): The first route I played, with the most involved plot. That kind of was its downfall though, a lot of focus and words was spent on resolving the plot and the payoff/solution was good, but the way to it was a bit of a slog. It definitely dragged in the middle, and I would recommend using the skip button during some scenes. It gave me true-ending vibes with its resolution though.
The relationship with Murasame was expanded upon in this route, and she gets a satisfying character arc and pay-off, although you don't notice that she's supposed to be 500 years old. They didn't really do anything with the concept and she feels more like a somewhat more mature girl in a young body, not an adult though. They could've definitely done a bit more with the well-spring of experiences Murasame has seen over her time, and her relationships with characters she has ostensibly been watching over for their entire lives.

A decent route but the middle part of the plot really dragged it down, I'd say this was thoroughly mediocre. I probably did Murasame a disservice by comparing her to Sothis from Fire Emblem 3 Houses which does a much better job of working with the 1000 year old loli archetype.

Mako(17): This route had a pretty good plot that kept me interested and was the best one in typing together plot and character development for the heroine. Also has one of the most amusing plot lines, sleepless in Hoori had me chuckling.
This route actually let the characters breathe and get to know each other before falling in love and felt a lot more plausible than some of the others. The characters also do a [b]great[/b] job communicating here, something that I was very surprised in an anime-inspired piece of media. Feelings were communicated and explored in a rather mature way. Ended with a very satisfying character-development based pay-off.

My favorite route overall.

Roka(20): Not much to write here, this and Koharu are bother side-character routes and basically just there, so you can romance other notable characters without making them actually plot-relevant. The ending was decent though, the plot while nothing to write home about was well-handled.
The relationship was alright, Roka could've been made a little more mature, but that would've gone against the innocent lily portrayal of all heroines, oh well. 

Koharu(14): Ah, the incest route. I played with the 18+ patch, this was the only route that was actually made worse by it, I feel. Very lame resolution overall and all in all not a great time for me.

Character limit reached, oops. 

Yoshino(16): This route had the best plot, I'd argue. The relationship was also well-explored. Contender for true-ending route.

[h1][u]My opinion on Senren＊Banka[/u][/h1]

[b]Story[/b]

☑ Very good
☐ Good
☐ Average
☐ Fair
☐ Nonexistent

For my part, the story is really captivating, we feel well the universe and the Japanese tradition through Senren Banka even if all the elements of the story are fictional as for example the city "Hoori". Who says Visual Novel, says multiple possible choices after the common story. In this game, 6 different routes bring us a lot of perceptives on the course of the adventure of our hero. Of course, it is possible to do the routes in the order, it will not change the way you perceive the game, the choice will be made according to your attraction on each heroine of the game. But you have to keep in mind that some roads will seem less interesting than others, despite that, I still advise you to do them all, you will have a global vision of the game! 

A little advice to unlock all the routes, if you are like me who has the laziness to look for them all, a small Google search and hop, it's settled! :)


[b]Audio (OST...)[/b]

☑ Excellent
☐ Good
☐ Average
☐ Bad
☐ Unpleasant

I was really won over by the opening music, it was this music that drove me to play this Visual Novel. Overall, I thought the OSTs reflected the environment of the story very well. 


[b]Translation[/b]

☐ Not translated *not yet*
☐ Disappointing
☐ Quite a few mistakes
☑ Nickel
☐ Translated into all languages

For French speakers looking for a Visual Novel in French, it's not going to be that easy... On the other hand if you have an intermediate level of English, you can enjoy this game to the fullest, it offers English that is not too difficult to understand! If you know Chinese or Japanese, it's even better! 


[b]Price[/b]

☐ Free
☐ Well worth it
☑ Normal "quality"/price ratio
☑ To buy on sale
☐ Way too expensive for what it is

Its normal price is 29,99€, I bought it at 19,19€, about 10€ less. I think the normal price is a bit high, that's why I waited for a promotion before enjoying Senren Banka. At the moment, all Yuzusoft's VNs are about this price, it's understandable, since the company buys the license and takes care of the translation and development of the system to implement their translation. 


[b]Lifetime[/b]

☐ Very long (+100h)
☑ Long (40-100h)
☐ Medium (25-40h)
☐ Short (8-25h)
☐ Very short (0-8h)

On my end, I was able to unlock all the routes and achievements in the game for a total of 50h of play. This seems pretty long to me for a Visual Novel, it will depend on how fast you read. 


[b]Audience[/b]

☐ Children
☑ Teenagers
☑ Adults

This game is basically an Eroge, the developers decided to remove the erotic scenes to target a wider audience on Steam, however the +18 version is available for free on the NekoNyan website for those who want the original version of the game.


[b]Config required[/b]

☐ Very low config
☑ Low-end / entry-level mid-range PC
☐ Mid-range PC / high-end entry
☐ High end PC
☐ NASA PC

Almost all Visual Novels do not require a graphics card to run the game, a processor is more than enough, however let's not exaggerate, 2000s PCs are not going to run the game...


[h1][u]Conclusion[/u][/h1]

I was pleasantly surprised by the structure of the story, we feel that it is not a simple romance story, there is a whole work behind made by the author. Currently my very first VN from Yuzusoft, I highly recommend it!

112803309.review:
Yuzusoft just doesn't miss with their solid "Pure Love" Comedy Galges. Senren＊Banka is no exception and is just another good entry in their catalog. Senren＊Banka compared to the other available Yuzusoft titles on steam leans more into traditional Japanese culture with the protagonist moving to a small village in a rural part of Japan reminiscent of P4 with Inaba if you've played that. Overall I enjoyed all the routes, and each heroine had an interesting enough character arc beyond the common route to read to the end. I think Mako's was my favorite to read, the writers got her gap moe tuned just right especially with her playful personality. I loved the gimmick with the Murasame sword, and the curse of the village this time around. If you have never played a Yuzusoft title they play out somewhat similarly, but they differentiate themselves with varying designs and character traits for the heroines. And then there's always a specific motif, setting, or theme they go with. It's just really all in the small nuanced details that allow individual Yuzusoft titles to stand on their own. 

The artwork is great as always with a signature style that when you see it you know you're reading a Yuzusoft VN. The OST is appropriate for the setting with some fun upbeat tracks thrown in the mix as well. Pacing is also decent, not perfect, but wasn't to the point I felt like things were moving way too slowly or too quickly with not enough narrative development. Also as always vocal performances were great, everyone from main cast to side characters made Hoori feel lively. 

I mean what else can you say, you get quality when you get a Yuzusoft VN, at worst they're alright, and at their best they're comfy and entertaining. Although preference and what you're looking for also plays a part, if you have certain expectations that aren't realistic you will probably find yourself disappointed. But as I stated before Senren＊Banka is another solid title in their catalog, not my personal favorite Yuzusoft title, but is worth a read for Moege enthusiasts.

112619708.review:
I just 100% all the routes and I figured I may as well write a review. My "hours played" stat is a little inflated from leaving it on overnight a few times, but I still spent quite a bit of time with it.

I'm no VN expert, as I've only ever really delved into the original Fate Stay Night and Katawa Shoujo. That being said, Senren Banka was a pretty decent Visual Novel, with high production value. A few routes are very good, and I found that my favorite was Murasame's route. All of the main routes (Yoshino, Lena, Murasame, Mako) are well fleshed out- some more than others. Roka/Koharu routes are the least involved, and feels like a side story more than anything. 

The H-Scenes- there's plenty of them. I played with the optional uncensored patch. Each route consists of several H-Scenes after the relationships blossom. Personally, I could have done with more character development / character moments than so many H-Scenes, but that's just me! When I say I want more PLOT, I don't mean it ironically. 

The main character is dense as hell, and sometimes annoying. The routes are very lengthy, often without real substance. However, despite the flaws, I found that many of the character moments were well executed. The banter between the characters can be very funny, and many of the more dire moments hit with appropriate impact, with many sad emotional moments. Sometimes the feels are there, and that's a good thing. It means I ended up liking the characters, but as a result, I feel a little underwhelmed they weren't developed further. 

While I may have many negative things to say about Senren Banka, I wouldn't have 100% it if I didn't enjoy it! It was a good time, and I do recommend giving it a look if you like VNs. Murasame's route had lots of laughs and feels, and I loved it. Playing Senren Banka was worth it for that route alone, as it hit on some interesting subject matter which I found particularly interesting and not often explored. Is Senren Banka worth it? Sure! It's not perfect, but there's no denying that it's a well crafted VN.

111183964.review:
This is my second Yuzusoft game, and by this point, I’m a fan of the company. Why?

Yes, it is a classical tropey tale about a Japanese dude who breaks the town’s Excalibur… er, katana in the stone, and now has to live at the shrine where it was kept and marry the shrine maiden. Of course, there are other girls involved in the mix, such as the loyal ninja girl whose family has served the shrine maiden for generations, the scaredy sword spirit of the katana, a gorgeous foreigner exchange student, the mandatory childhood friend and cousin, a curse hanging over the town they have to deal with… you know, the works.
But in true Yuzusoft manner, they quickly make use of the charming personalities and quirks of each girl, to the point that all grow on you by the end of the common route and you are wondering which heroine’s route to start first.

This is because of how skillfully they weave the tale of Hoori’s curse and how it affects our characters, and how each character represents one part of the solution (my recommended order: Yoshino > Roka and Koharu > Mako > Lena > Murasame) to the whole mystery. And it really is one hell of a tale, delightfully intricate and full to the brim with colorful Japanese folklore. Plus the characters themselves are just as fun to watch in Yuzusoft’s classic “Another View”, a feature I love and wish to see appear more often in VNs, where you get to see the perspective of other characters aside from the MC.

That way, you get to see Yoshino’s seriousness as a shrine maiden and funny innocence as a girl (her achievements are SO. DAMN. HILARIOUS.), Mako’s fierce loyalty and girlish femininity, Lena’s charming naivete and unique cultural mishaps (kudos for the translators for succeeding in properly translating her linguistic blunders, that’s no mean feat), Murasame’s regality and childishness, and Roka and Koharu as the ones to show you the less “arcane” side of Hoori, love the cultural bits they provide.
Plus Masaomi himself, as a good Yuzusoft MC, has real charm, and does not feel constrained by his tropes. He really grows during the story, and has some great dynamics with all the characters, making you cheer for him.

All of this, to the beat of some nice, relaxing music, neatly dressed up with some proper classic Japanese musical instruments that truly give of the vibe a town with its haunted mountain should have.

I seriously wish this game got an anime adaptation. Its tale is easier to bring to anime than Sabbat of the Witch’s (less… risqué scenes to worry about). It has all the right pieces, even if they adapt the story to only follow the “true path”. But if they go the Yosuga no Sora route and adapt all the heroine routes in true Vn fashion… THAT would be interesting.
So yeah, I highly recommend it. Does not matter if you are a fan of VNs or not. Good tale. Accessible for everyone.

What’s that? The +18 patch content? Yeah, get it if you want from Nekonyan. Yuzusoft makes those scenes interesting and have relevance in the story when necessary; though IMO, the story is just fine without the extra spice.
