107426560.review:
Feels like I'm doing something illegal by giving this a thumbs down, so I want to apologize to those who really enjoyed this VN in advance. Guess I'm just playing the devil's advocate.

tldr - It's not a bad game by any means. But despite the game's beautiful setting and music, I personally don't think Senren Banka meets my expectations enough to recommend it due to its poor character and story immersion.

Yuzusoft usually does great at making cute romantic stories. Senren Banka is no exception to this. However, it's exactly that and not much more despite its amazing potential. In comparison to other Yuzusoft titles, Senren Banka has the most interesting premise in its lore and story, but probably the worse execution in telling it which greatly impacts its ability to immerse its audience.

Instead of using the setting and allowing us to immerse more into its characters and world, the main story feels more like a simple blockade of boring fight scenes and out-of-place fan service that we have to forcibly read through in order to enter each heroine route. Many of the individual routes themselves also come off as questionable. This is because they basically consist of awkward romantic developments in the form of unnaturally horny and cheesy character interactions that further pulls us away from any sort of seriousness in the narrative that was established. Considering how long and slow the main story line is before we even get to the individual character routes, the main story tricks us into thinking there will be some kind of deeper lore to help develop our character relationships, which unfortunately there really isn't. By the time I even finished the common route, I couldn't help but think about how bland and shallow everything was and many times I felt like dropping it. It ultimately lead to me having little to no urge to pursue some individual heroine routes because I didn't find them interesting enough. I suppose this could just be me expecting too much. After all, this is a Yuzusoft game; They aren't particularly well known for creating deep stories.

Senren Banka also suffers from a much poorer cast dynamic in comparison to its other Yuzusoft titles. In terms of the cast, its difficult to pin-point what I felt went wrong. While all heroines and side characters feel great in representing their individual personalities, there seems to be an issue when you put them together. Unlike other Yuzusoft titles, Senren Banka lacks any sort of solid relationship between the heroines and other characters outside of the MC in order to establish a strong and compelling group dynamic. It feels harsh to say, but some characters are just completely irrelevant and meaningless to the overall story due to their relationship and poor screen time with other characters. There's not enough development or meaningful interactions from some characters to justify them being there in the first place and it wouldn't be an oversight to say that some characters, if removed from the story, would have no impact on the main cast or story narrative at all. 

To explain how I feel: Imagine watching your typical anime or show that takes place in a setting with multiple people in the background. You see the main characters having an important discussion, and suddenly one of the background characters walk up and starts talking to the main characters mid-conversation, while contributing nothing to said conversation. You scratch your head confused, wondering why they're even there in the first place and later on you kind of forget they even existed. That's the usual gist of some conversations and it's basically wasted time.

You can argue that this could just be due to the story's setting, as all of our characters aren't naturally forced together; like in a school or a club room. But nevertheless, its kind of a shame, as I feel Yuzusoft games usually excel at character to character dynamics and having them all play a part in the story.

Unfortunately for me, I'd say Senren Banka is on the lower end of Yuzusoft visual novels. I would still recommend this for people who simply want to turn their brain off and enjoy a cute romantic comedy with a rural Japanese setting. For people looking for more or expecting quality similar to other Yuzusoft titles, I personally don't think Senren Banka matches up to them due to the reasons stated above. So, I find it hard to recommend this if you've already read the others.

[hr][/hr]

EDIT (2/12/2022): So, I convinced myself to finish all the routes despite losing interest and dropping the game for a bit. For reference, I had only finished Mako's, Yoshino's, and Murasame's routes when I initially decided to drop and review the game. I have to say, I enjoyed Lena's route quite a bit, as the narrative in her route is far more enjoyable in terms of the story and romantic development. Her route explores and expands much deeper into the plot and also allows us to have the entire cast coming together more often, much to my pleasure, as opposed to the other heroine routes having most of the cast seemingly disappear for the majority of the story.

However, my previous negative points still stand so I won't be changing my mind on keeping this a thumbs down. Roka's and Koharu's routes didn't present anything special to me either, as expected from side characters who rarely had screen time in the common route. Sorry.

As of writing this review i have just finished my first route in which i ended up with Lena's ending.

Firstly i'm very new to visual novels and have never properly played one. That being said from the very get go i was engrossed, from the masterfully executed music and the smart witty banter that had me cracking up multiple times throughout, there was never a dull moment. The in game menu provides a helpful flow chart that lets you see the choices you chose and the part of the story you are at, which lets you jump to any point in the story giving easy access to parts you might want to revisit. The characters in Senren Banka are crafted in a way that really emphasises the big moments in the story, sharing dialogue that feels meaningful only helped by being performed by some amazing voice actors that only enhances your immersion. In total the route i played took around 19 hours to finish which as a new comer was a manageable length never stretching interactions out longer than they need to be while at the same time never rushing important and memorable moments. As this was my first experience into Visual novels I was cautious of starting one as from the outside looking in they can seem intimidating to get into, however after finishing what i have of the story i am only ready to dive into the other routes and start the whole experience all over again. In conclusion Senren Banka is a story you don't want to miss out on and i highly implore you, no matter if your new to visual novels or a veteran to give it a try.

Senren Banka is the first Visual Novel I ever got into. At first I played the free version, but I liked it so much that I decided to purchase it. I have no regrets at all, in fact I highly recommend it.

The plot in itself isn't particularly original, it's basically "average dude moves from city to a small country village, becomes sort of a chosen hero and gets surrounded by cute girls in the process". The game does a good job at establishing an interesting setting and cast of characters though.

If you are looking for a cool VN to read and relax after a tiresome day, I recommend Senren Banka. I can't stress enough how much I enjoyed this VN, it made me put off other games, anime and books because I just wanted so much to go on with the story.

96788522.review:
[quote]Uncensor patch required: Yes.
Mosaic censorship: Yes.[/quote]

[b]My Score:[/b] 9,5/10

[h1]Prologue[/h1]
Onsens, the beloved hot springs of Japan, where several cities became tourist spots due to their hot springs. Among these, one in particular, the small town near the mountains called Hoori, where our young protagonist, the student Masaomi will live in the inn managed by his grandfather, after his mother's "gentle" suggestion of spending time with his grandparents. When the protagonist arrives in the city, he is received by his cousin, the small and calm pink-haired Kurama, in addition to his childhood friends, the womanizer Rentarou and the young Maniwa, who are always ready to help and offer to show the city to the protagonist ^ ^

The first stop for the group is at the city's sanctuary, where the legend says the legendary katana Murasame waits embedded in a stone for someone worthy to wield it again. Innocently, the group decides to try to draw the sword, everyone fails until Masaomi's turn, who, concentrating and using all his strength, ends up breaking the katana into two parts. While waiting for his punishment to be decided, Masaomi is visited by a small girl with green hair who goes by the same name as the broken sword, Murasame. She claims to be the guardian of the sword, repairs it with magic, and tells Masaomi he was chosen. After the adults know that he is the chosen one, the young man's life completely changes, because as he is the bearer of the katana, now he has to marry the daughter of the priest, the beautiful and slightly sulky Yoshino, while trying to not make her angry, because her maid Mako, while a good cook and full of "pure" insinuations, is a trained ninja too! And so begins the protagonist's first crazy day in this small town. ^^

[h1]Characters[/h1]
After the madness of the first day, we are gradually introduced to each of the 6 girls in this small village. Tomotake Yoshino is the first to stand out because of her arranged wedding to the bearer of Murasame. She is friendly, with long white hair, and despite refusing the protagonist and having opposite tastes to him at first, with the passage of time she starts to open up. Still in the same residence, we have Hitachi Mako, the kind housekeeper responsible for cooking and cleaning, but also a ninja trained in all kinds of techniques with a sharp tongue more dangerous than any weapon. Her only weakness? Being afraid of heights. Lena Liechtenauer, a foreigner who loves everything related to the culture of Japan, always wants to learn more including improving her Japanese pronunciation, but be careful not to leave anything "pure" near her, because if she sees it, her face will be redder than a tomato! Maniwa Roka, childhood friend of the protagonist and great connoisseur of the city and its sights, along with little Kurama Koharu, cousin of the protagonist who is always willing to help. Completing the group we have the literally ever-present Murasame, the spirit of the sword that follows the protagonist everywhere, who curiously fears ghosts despite being a spirit herself. With six different girls, it remains to be seen which route the story will continue. ^^ 

[h1]Art & sound[/h1]
With beautiful art made by the Yuzusoft studio, the same one that made Sabbat of the Witch, throughout the story we are given beautiful art for both the characters and the scenarios, full of details, including some very funny expressions of the characters you can see again in the gallery after completing the first route. Along with art, we have the pleasant and relaxing soundtrack that never fails to make me relax, including Japanese voices for all characters with the exception of the protagonist, including in the "pure" moments. ^^

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Produced by Yuzusoft Studio and translated by NekoNyan Ltd. Studio, Senren * Banka, a funny and hilarious story of our young protagonist, who in less than 24 hours after arriving in the city of Hoori sees his life totally change thanks to a katana, making him now one of the protectors of the city, at the same time that he has to keep going to school and try to survive his new life together with the heiress of the sanctuary, in an adventure full of fun and exciting moments whose ending, and the girl with whom he will end up, depends entirely on the player's choices ^^

96227327.review:
Fairly better than Riddle Joker, but not as good as Sanoba Witch in my opinion. The action/fantasy element was better integrated than RJ but SW used theirs better.

Setup for Linux Users: https://www.protondb.com/app/1144400#g9XIyrD4fn . For some reason it's the roughest to setup of all the Yuzusoft titles on Steam and Steam Overlay doesn't work half the time for me. YMMV ofc based on your system.

Like the RJ and SW, it has a "What we want," theme to the story and a sub-theme for a specific subject. If RJ was focused on the subject of "Secrets," and SW was focused on "Communication," then SB is "Family and that is what routes revolve on.

Route order wise, I recommend going Mako > Yoshino > Murasame > Lena. Weirdly Yoshino's route isn't the most wider-plot relevant or even the longest like how Ayase's route has the most plot points in it and Nene's route is worth two routes. I like the treatment of the mini routes here, Koharu and Roka sharing a "common" route that diverges based on who you choose so unlike the other Yuzusoft mini routes, it has more meat to it. You can play them as a snack in between the main routes.

Yoshino was OK IMO. Out of the 3 Yuzusoft games I've played, she's the least interesting main heroine. She's the typical Yuzusoft main heroine; most popular girl, has a bit of a chip on her shoulder, has some secrets, and under some stressful circumstances related to the main plot. Her plot has the closest relation to "family" - it's okay, not great, not bad.

Mako is the resident lewd girl of the game - she has 6 lewd scenes (though 2 of those are mini ones), two more than the others. Her route is kinda a rehash of Yoshino's and a sneak peak to Lena's route. Pretty much the reason I like her route is because once she became independent and accepted herself, she gets pretty lewd and I like lewd girls.

A version of Murasame's route is implied to happen after all the other routes. Her route is the one with the most feels as it concerns the weight of being a 500 years old ghost that couldn't be touched. I like that she's very proactive about her romantic interest. Outside of that, her non-romantic subplot concerns the future of the village, and I'd assume a version of it always happens in the other routes.

Before I get to Lena, I wanna talk about the other stuff first.

Roka and Koharu was okay. Koharu has a really cute design and mannerism but honestly that's the only thing she had going for her - I'm startig to see a pattern in the type of character that gets the Yuzusoft mini route treatment. Roka though? She makes me want more older ladies heroines - she has a job, she has her own dreams and goals, she has some good conversations and her own insecurities, it's all done pretty well despite how short it was that I wish we could just slash Koharu for more Roka.

Engine is always the industry gold standard - we now have flowchart system and only a few UX thing left to be ironed out. I wish this is the industry standard as this polish is part of why I got so into Yuzusoft stuff recently - it's just the most friction free VN reading I ever had.

Music was okay. I wish they leaned more on the traditional Japan aspect as the most unique BGMs are the ones that leaned more into it. The leitmotif was good thougha and the OP was pretty much the best too - though it's a shame that the 18+ patch doesn't decensor the Steam version's OP.

Art was good and memorable, though the character design was just okay for me. The uniform design was cool though - mustn't have been easy because it was a mix of multi-layer colorful traditional Japanese clothing and what passes as a 'uniform' but I'm glad they leaned into it because it does contributed the aesthetic it has.

The lewds was meh. It was a disappointment coming from SB's which has better interaction that I can get really into it. I think it was still better than most of RJ's lewds and at least it doesn't feel tacked on or get in the way of the plot, but after the first one it does felt like it's just to fill quota.



I think that's all to speak aside for Lena. So, anyway, I think Lena is best girl and my favorite Yuzusoft heroine. And I'm going to explain why in the spoilers.

They really managed to nail the mix of foreign values and her adjusting to the environment she's in, to make a pretty unique character. Yes, there is some foreigner stereotypes put into it as well, but it's fine as it doesn't feel they're going beyond anything that is in good fun.

Oh nevermind that she's not some American or English foreigner - she's a Scandinavian (Finland I think) who went to Japan alone and for a job and exchange program in boonies because of her love for the culture. Her problem with Japanese phrases is understandable in the Japanese version as it was usually just one syllable off from what she meant to say, like "okotta" and "nokotta", an understandable confusion. At the same time, it doesn't prevent her from expressing herself and she's actually pretty fluent in the language too aside for those understandable contextual issues.

She's pretty much the most expressive character in the entire game - even the main character remarking that watching her watch movies is like watching four people's worth of expressions. At the same time, she's no simple emotional girl - if anything, she has the most sense and sensitivity of the heroines.

[spoiler]Her route is the only one where you didn't win by just fighting. No, she's so sensitive that she could sense the pain behind the cursed spirit's existence, and it allowed her to empathize with it without being swallowed by its taint.

In fact, it's amazing that without even knowing anything about the myths of dreams and food in underworld, she could feel that something was off from the dream she was trapped in. When pointed out as to the danger she could be in, she readily risks herself for her friends, and  when the MC stated that he will take responsibility for her, she remarked that she doesn't like the idea of the MC "taking responsibility for her" because it removes her agency to make a choice and bear its results and as they are in a relationship, it should be that they both take responsibility for each others.

She then proceeds to remove the MC's worry by showing him that no matter what happens they are connected under one sky and demonstrate it by having a video call with her family, showing that even if they can feel lonely at times, they will always be connected. It was enough that the MC then take the initiative of talking to his own family.

She managed to solve most of the issues, including the problem with tourism and what the village can do going forward, and IIRC only in her epilogue that it's mentioned that Murasama had her thing happen as well - which implied a lot - and even returned the cursed spirit into a guardian deity that is honored by the family and the village as they find out about the entire history of the curse.

Even the cursed spirit was taken by her as he makes her play the role of its sister, a goddess, as it shows the entire history of the curse which was only teased in Mako's route. Even the antagonist puts her on goddess tier! And she deserves it, not just for her character.[/spoiler]

I'm not usually into big breasts character but that is no mere big breasts - nay, those are embodiment of dreams and hopes on its own. The way it accentuate her plain work clothes, the way it stretches the cute "Oh, Fujiyama" print on her casual shirt, how it gets the strap of her bag stuck in the middle in her first appearance, even when it was more covered by the underclothes in her casual kimono the covered side-boobs still attracted attention, the way she had to admit that the cardigan wouldn't fit her breasts, and how it displayed her uniform tie which is stuck in the middle to mounds of hopes and dreams and just catches your attention.


So! Isn't! Lena! Liechtenaeur! The! BEST?!

I honestly thought that this game was overrated, the story is a generic chosen hero that saves a village from evil spirits where whenever he fights he always ends up escaping with nothing truly bad happening or he ends up winning the fight in the end.

The protagonist was pretty much the typical bland, dense protagonist that has nothing interesting to his character. At least the other characters are kind of good, exploring their routes was kind of fun, except when the game pulls you out of their side stories and forces you to read the main story. The romance on the other hand had no impact on me, mostly because I found it very lacking.

Most of the story is spent trying to solve the mystery as to why the town is cursed, which boiled down to the protagonist and his friends fighting the evil spirits (multiple times in the same locatiton) and collecting their shards since it served as a key to uncover it, what sucks is that it constantly shows the protagonist having multiple very boring training arcs where he slowly becomes stronger and once they actually beat the spirits they show them going to the towns doctor so she can inspect the pieces, every single time.

The choices are just there so you can get laid by one of the girls (including the protagonist cousin), there's no risk of anything bad happening to you or the characters.

The reason for the main villain to curse the town was just out of some generic vengeance.

Music was mostly not my thing, since most of the music is centralized around the traditional Japanese music genre.

I would only kind of recommend to buy the game on sale for the characters if you are interested in them and not for the main story since I personally found it boring, even though I forced myself to finish the main story and Lena's route (which her route offers the most important parts of the main story). There are way better mystery visual novels out there like Steins Gate and Danganronpa series, and if you want a good romance visual novel then just get Clannad. Leave a comment if you disagree with something that I said, but please keep in mind that this review was mostly me sharing my opinions of the game.

86725216.review:
If you liked Sabbat Of The Witch you're going to love this!

Not once did I get bored while reading this, it's just on a completely different level when it comes to the plot. Since every route reveals different aspects of the backstory within this VN you'll actually feel a lot more motivated to go through all of the routes to learn everything you can. 
As for the length of this VN... It's not really that different in terms of length when compared to Sabbat Of The Witch, however the hours you spend reading this are a lot more evenly distributed across different routes.

The UI has seen a substantial improvement when compared to Sabbat Of The Witch, with it feeling generally a lot more fluid and I actually found myself using gesture controls in this one. Flowchart makes it easier for you to change your choices made during the common route, allowing you to remold the decision path for a different route without the need to start the story from the beginning.

Soundtrack is great and fits the atmosphere really well. Having classic Japanese music with a modern twist to it was certainly a unique experience and just makes me crave for an option to buy the entire soundtrack so much more. 

As for the visuals? Stunning. The art style is the same as before but with another level of detail and deeper, more stunning colours. Also it's all in Full HD and I was comfortable reading this fullscreen on my 27" 2K monitor without any issues. 

Overall an excellent VN, probably the best one I've read so far. I highly recommend it.

84652336.review:
Hinamizawa-lite

Joking. Sorta. That aside, I gave the previous title, Sabbat of the Witch, a barely passing grade. Thus my surprise when this game turned out to be absolutely amazing. The story is great, a touch Higurashi-ish, but I'm not complaining. While the previous was an obvious shallow dating sim that happened to have other elements, this game has a strong focus that also happens to have the dating aspect. The music is solid - very well done, and has a distinct eastern feel to it. The little details such as UI, options, etc., are well polished, and it has a convenient flowchart system. It's also supported in multiple languages and doesn't seem too difficult a read, so I look forward to practicing my chinese and japanese by rereading this.

My only real complaint is that there's no 'true route'. Through the various routes you learn a lot of unique aspects about the main focus of the story, but you never get a chance to put them all together and really solve the issue. 

Overall: great game. I would even recommend this to people with little interest in visual novels that might want to give one a go. Maybe not as their first VN, but within the first few.

81586971.review:
Overall well-designed, with a great starting point. The game also has a flowchart feature that you can use to change your choices quickly and allows you to experiment on the choices you make. 

There are six heroines in total, although only three of them are the main heroines, as these three routes include the main conflict of the story (curse) into the plot of their story. Each heroine is unique, however, in their backgrounds and personalities, and their way of dealing with said curse. 

Each main heroine route reveals a different side of the curse, and so by reading all three you can get a better picture of the true nature of the curse and its history. As such, the heroines have different ways to deal with the curse, which matches their own personalities.

The three others deal with a different problem, as they have little to no connection to the curse (except for one, but it doesn't really count as it doesn't really deal with the curse). Because of this, their routes are considerably lighter than the three main ones, with a more slice of life feeling. 

Even so, each route is fun to read, The scenes are heartwarming and the comedy is great.

[spoiler]Lena is the best route[/spoiler]
[spoiler]Murasame is NOT a main heroine[/spoiler]
It's from nekonyansoft, so [spoiler]get the patch from nekonyansoft website[/spoiler]

78978638.review:
First of all, thanks for bringing Senren Banka to the west, NekoNyan.

Of all Yuzusoft games I played, this one is by far my favorite, for me it deserves being bought at full price, it has a long length for a VN, but that's just my personal opinion. 

Pros:
-Beautiful and relaxing OST.
-Charming characters.
-The girls aren't constantly fighting for the MC. 
-High resolution CG's.
-Panic button (it really saved me).
-Interesting story, and routes
-Easy system to get the route you want.
-Mako
-Murasame singing Kagome Kagome, and Toryanse

Cons:
-It takes some time getting to the H scenes, other than that, I have nothing else to say, I really enjoyed the whole VN


-The OST is perfect for this game, and since I love japanese instruments, I have nothing to complain about. I fell in love in the first couple of minutes

- I have a 1080p monitor, and usually for VN's, if I play in fullscreen, the CG's start getting blurry, and I have to play it windowed in a lower resolution (which I hate). 
 On the other hand, for this VN, you can easily play fullscreen without losing the CG quality.

-The designs are gorgeous and every character is really charming, it's the first time I can say wholeheartedly "I like every single character" in a VN. And the best thing about it, is that you have none of that sh*tty rom-com troupe of the girls fighting over the MC.

-It is one of those VN in which the more routes you play, the more you understand about the game, which normally, is kinda of bothersome (if you just play the routes for the girls you like), but on this one, I really enjoyed learning more about the world, and also, there weren't incongruencies you usualy see in VN's build this way

-And if you are interested in the +18 aspect, I will say, the scenes are really good, as for the amount of H scenes with each girl, for the main 4 girls, is 3(with the exception of Mako who has 1 more CG in which she is playing with herself). For the other 2, it's 2. You then have the after story which  adds one more scene to every girl.
 If you are wandering how  long it takes to get to the H scenes, I will say it takes quite some time

75382413.review:
[i]Disclaimer: There is a free R18 patch available from NekoNyan's official website which adds cut content (mainly H-Scene related) back to the game. I can't speak for the cut version as I have only played the uncut one.[/i]

I'm going to keep this fairly short instead of doing a thorough review, but I've added some thoughts on various aspects of the game below if you want to dive deeper.

I've enjoyed Senren*Banka and highly recommend checking this one out. The overall focus of the game is the curse of the town Hori, with the protagonist being an outsider thrown in and the four main heroines being related to or influenced by the curse in one way or another. 
While romance is a big focus in each of the four main heroine routes, all of them come with actual plot to explore (and extra "plot" if you have the patch installed). There are two additional routes (namely Koharu and Roka), but these are just an extra that do not tackle the core plot in any way.

All main heroines are very likable, some especially moreso once you enter their routes. Murasame is best girl tho.

I've clocked in about 50 hours at the time of writing, but considering AFK time, occasional skipping, etc I would guess the actual read time to be at around 40-45ish hours.

Without further ado here are some notes about the game:

[h1]Story, Routes and Recommended Play Order[/h1]

[b]Minor (marked) spoilers in this section![/b]

While the overall route order is not enforced and up for the player to decide, in my opinion some routes are better played before others as you can see below. 
Each route will have its main heroine as a romance focus but also some sort of sub-plot to deal with. Here are some notes about each route:

Yoshino's route explores the curse theme [spoiler]and the situation of the Tomotake family further. [/spoiler] This one feels like a natural continuation of the common route, and should be played first.

Mako's route tackles the curse theme from a different perspective, with more details on it following in Lena's route (Although you shouldn't play Lena's route first, see Lena's section). 
The focus of the route is Mako herself and [spoiler] the problem of falling in and experiencing love. Since the theme doesn't go far beyond romance (which the other routes also have), it's the weakest route in my personal opinion. [/spoiler] 
If you aren't playing Yoshino first, this one works as a first route too.

Lena's route answers a lot of questions that come up in both Mako's and Yoshino's route, [spoiler] while also resolving the curse problem in a manner that feels like a "true" ending to the curse itself. [/spoiler] Whether this one or Murasame's is the actual "true" route is up for debate.
Since Yoshino, Mako and Lena routes focus heavily on the curse you should do this route after reading the other two.

Murasame's route shifts the focus from cleansing the curse to its aftermath instead, [spoiler]with Murasame herself now being simply a ghost without any duties and the town facing the economical impact of losing one of the main attrations for tourists.[/spoiler]
Similar to Mako's route the focus here is on Murasame herself, with the main difference being Murasame's special circumstances (her being a spiritual being and the caretaker of Murasamemaru and all). This one can be played at any time, although playing it later will probably be more satisfying. 
As I said before either this one or Lena's route can be considered the "true" route of the game.

Koharu/Roka duo-route is a bonus route that splits into two mini routes for each sub-heroine towards the end. Both routes are fairly unrelated to the initial common route plot and focus entirely on [spoiler]the cafe and the related girls.[/spoiler]
You can play this route at any point (although you need to clear any main route first in order to unlock it), but if you aren't interested in either of them you can safely skip them.

As such my recommended play order would be Yoshino > Mako > Lena > Murasame, with Koharu and Roka tossed in anywhere inbetween.

[h1] Art and Sound Impressions [/h1]
The game features roughly 10 beautiful event CG with an additional 4 H-Scenes for each heroine. The count is a little on the low side, however there's lots of cute chibi SD art to make up for it.
The liberal use of character sprites during regular scenes also helps to alleviate this issue. It's impressive how lively a character can turn out if you let them change sprites even multiple times during the same voice line, even if there aren't all that many pose and face variants.

The soundtrack is great too, with a theme befitting the village Hori. Each heroine also has their own theme in both a normal and more intimate variation, as well as their own ED song. The regular songs while playing shine the most though.

Overall voice acting is great too with all non-protagonist voice lines fully voiced. 
Some heroines like to get loud as they become flustered though, so an option to limit the discepancy between whispering and shouting would have been nice (to be fair, there is an integrated quick-access sound slider in the chat box to mitigate this). This is only a little gripe though.

[h1] Technical Stuff [/h1]

As mentioned before this version is a porn-free release, with a free patch available from their official website. Installing the patch doesn't break anything on the steam-side of things, so big thumbs up here. 
There are some scenes that will be foggy or censored in other ways to hide naked bodies, but it doesn't affect the overall experience of the core story. Whether you should use the patch or not is entirely up to personal preference.

The game runs in a native 1080p window, but scales just fine up to 1440p when applying fullscreen. The window can be freely resized (while still maintaining aspect ratio), but there is no easy way to reset it to its native 1080p resolution once you do so. Swapping between window mode and fullscreen can be done smoothly on the fly, and thanks to the "panic button" minimize feature you can easily mute and pop the game into the background while multitasking. (Even if the feature isn't quite intended that way) 

The "Flowchart" feature, combined with a powerful backlog that allows jumping between scenes, voice-lines and even previewing backgrounds while browsing makes it especially easy to navigate to your next route or favourite scene. This is also very handy for completionists. It would be great if this became a standard for visual novels going forward.
There's also a voice-line bookmark feature. This is a niche feature but I found myself using it for funny moments, so I'm glad it was included, but I can't see many players using it.

There's also a lot of customizability in the game's settings menu that I would like to see in many visual novels going forward. Things like your typical text size, speed as well as background and read-text colors, but also other things like auto-skipping, BGM balance split for voice lines and mouse gestures. 
Full customization of the chatbox bar and mouse gestures, as well as a touch-UI option for streaming to a phone makes for a very enjoyable reading experience.

In the game's "Extra" section (namely the Gallery) you'll find unlocked CG and music, as well as a Scene select for H-Scenes and a Sprite Mode. The Sprite Mode allows you to put characters in your preffered poses on the background of your choice. Nice feature to have, although I've personally only used it to review character outfits.

73219803.review:
[b]MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD![/b]

Since this game came out a year after Sanoba Witch (both made by Yuzusoft), I expected some slight improvements and thankfully I felt like there were more than enough improvements.

The most notable was how the main story never lost its focus. It either got resolved during the common route or it expanded on certain character routes, this is a huge plus. Speaking of which, each of the main 4 routes (Yoshino, Mako, Murasame, Lena) were super good. All had something different to offer, all of them had some very memorable moments and genuine surprises. Not to say I didn't enjoy the side routes which felt like a seperate common route, splitting into two choices at the end (Roka and Koharu).

Another big thing is, that while the story was set up in a way that Yoshino is definitely the main choice, the game never forced me to actually pick her (like how in Sanoba Witch it kinda didn't really make a lot of sense to pick anyone else than Nene). Every girl had a fairly even chance, I never felt like the game truly ever showed heavy favoritism towards Yoshino. Truly intimate moments with the girls (which actually had any meaning) only show up on their respective routes. I don't know if character favoritism is a thing in previous Yuzusoft games, but even if it isn't, I feel like this is at least somewhat important.

I really liked the character development, especially with Yoshino and Murasame. It was such a heartwarming experience to see them change throughout the story, becoming much more free and open people. It was well written and well acted.

The MC is very likeable and relatable. Sure he's a bit exaggerated, but I think it was the healthiest thing to do in this game's case.

The music was also great, I liked most of the tracks in the game.

Now for the routes:

[b]Yoshino[/b]: When I completed this route, I felt super emotional with my teary eyes and felt like it was one of the most fulfilling story I've ever read. You know the writing is good when all the feels suddenly hit you, and hit you hard. While I felt like some important pieces were missing, the story still felt complete to me.

[b]Mako[/b]: While I think her's was the weakest of the 4 routes, I'd stay it was still "good" if not anything else. It was nice to see Mako's viewpoint, her cute quirks and weaknesses and just generally getting to know her better. I think it just simply lacked some of the impact Yoshino's route had if I had to pick on something.

[b]Murasame[/b]: For whatever reason, I didn't have a lot of expectations regarding her route, but I ended up liking it a lot more than I thought I would. Since in her case almost everything was resolved during the common route, it lacked some tension... or at least I first thought. While the outcome became fairly obvious soon and lost that impact quickly, I liked it for what it was. Oh BOY Masaomi was an absolute BADASS in this route. I could feel my beard growing from all that testosterone and manliness.

[b]Lena[/b]: Seriously, was this the canon route or what? We got to know a LOT more... and I mean A LOT more information about the main story (curse, the past, etc.) in this route than in Yoshino's, which hid a lot of the finer details. As far as the routes themselves goes, there is no competition, this one's the best. It involves the other characters a lot more as well, not like in other routes where most of the other characters become more or less side characters. Here, everyone gets together while Lena still remains in the focus, as she should. Someone mentioned here that Lena might be secretly the main girl and I kinda agree.

As for the characters themselves:

[b]Yoshino[/b]: I absolutely loved Yoshino. She goes through the most changes in a positive way, while her charming quirks still remain. Her change felt super genuine and not forced. She was also cute as heck.

[b]Mako[/b]: I didn't feel particularly attached to Mako, but she's a more than fine character nonetheless. Her story was interesting and she showed that she's a lot more vulnerable than she lets on.

[b]Murasame[/b]: I usually don't like the loli archetype, mostly because I find their personalities and voices annoying, not in her case. She was an absolute sweetheart and her VA did an amazing job so that she'd feel genuine instead of being annoying. Very fun personality.

[b]Lena[/b]: Did you say positivity? Again, did I hear you saying POSITIVITY? Sure that's not all there's to it, but I absolutely adored Lena and felt like that she might as well be the main heroine. Of course she wasn't perfect or invulnerable, but she was definitely the most honest and genuine girl out of all of them right from the getgo. She was also the funniest girl, no contest there. I'm pretty sure if you outright hate Lena you're a bad person.

[b]Roka[/b]: Like, holy hell she looks hotter than the hottest sun in the universe. I usually don't talk about how characters look, but damn that's DEFINITELY an attractive 2D character. I don't especially like the "Onee-san" archetype, but in this case, it was never overplayed or was overused. Her personality felt unique and very fun, I wish she was one of the main heroines. At least you can romance her so I can't complain too much.

[b]Koharu[/b]: With Mako, I didn't feel very attached to Koharu, but at the same time I had no issues with her. She was really cute, but that's all there's to it in my case.

I had an absolute blast playing this. All of the VAs did a fantastic job in general, especially Yoshino's, Roka's, Murasame's and Lena's. I enjoyed even some of the side characters as well, especially Genjuuro. He's pretty complex for just a side character and also likeable. I'm definitely recommending this game!

71245891.review:
This is a difficult one. Did I regret reading this? No. But I had my own reasons for sticking with it, like practising my Japanese, and an academic interest in Japan in general, and visual novels as a form of Japanese popular culture in particular. Did I like it? On balance, yes, but the same caveat applies, with the addition that some of what I liked probably did not survive the translation. Did I buy the soundtrack? Another yes. But the question is, would I recommend this, and I honestly don't know to whom I would.

If you're new to visual novels, surely there are better and more beginner-friendly options.
If you have a few under your belt, chances are you'll find it mediocre, and who has time for that?
If you're a veteran you've no need of my recommendation, one way or the other.

FWIW, a lot of what I liked -- the soundtrack, art, setting, and world-building -- can be fully experienced in the free trial. If that captivates you, even knowing that it doesn't get better than that, and considerably worse in some aspects, go for it.

P.S.: There is a free patch with additional content to be had on NekoNyan's website. Though honestly, if you're on the fence about these things, read without, you're not missing anything.

While Senren * Banka isn't the longest VN I've played, it's certainly the one I played the longest, from February to June(!?).  The main story was engaging enough, and each character's route diverged quite a bit rather than "same event but different person."  The artwork was cute, colorful, and attractive, and although the girls tended toward large chests it wasn't as pronounced as for example Wagamama High Spec.

The voice acting was a delight.  The voices were well-done and expressive.  Each of the characters had unique speech patterns and affectations, from Mako's "choppiri" and Murasame's "wagahai" to Lena's "tatami-gami."  The completely adorable voice failures were superbly bookmark-able as well.

The writing was mostly good.  While there were parts I wish they'd done differently such as the infrequent occasions where main character Masaomi was a jerk, overall it didn't leave much room to gripe.

That leaves the ever-looming elephant in the room, Localization.  The localization was solidly mediocre: I've seen better, I've seen worse, and most of the time it got the job done, but it was also inconsistent, ranging from a faithful re-telling to creative fan-fiction.  The localization lacked the feeling of overall consistency and direction characteristic of a top-tier localization, with the same phrases used in the same contexts localized differently at different times.  Lena's route provides perhaps the best and worst examples of this, where some of her catastrophic Japanese failures are explained clearly while other renderings are completely head-scratching.  In other places the translator didn't even try, for example turning "It's my first time enveloped in such soft fluffiness" into "I'm getting a lap pillow."

Fortunately, the game engine provides bilingual subs, so when I was dissatisfied I could read the original myself [spoiler]especially in the R-18 scenes unlocked by the publisher patch, which tended into the head-scratching realm[/spoiler].

Senren * Banka is not the deepest or most emotionally moving or twisted or surprising or beautiful or captivating but the content is good and there is a lot of it.  The pacing worked perfectly for shorter reading sessions when I'm home from work or between doing other things.  I see no reason to discourage buying it, and if you have any questions the free demo should let you know if you'd like it or not.

I was looking forward to completing the game so I could move on to others, but the feeling of completion is bitter-sweet: 
 It's been a long time since I wasn't playing Senren * Banka, and I'm going to miss hearing everyone's voices now that I'm all done.

70106415.review:
Very very solid VN from the makers of Sabbat of the Witch.  Compared to Sabbat, which is a very stock-standard school club romance VN, this one adds a bit of spice by focusing on more fantastical elements.  Still a highschool setting, but the school itself is really on the periphery--the focus is more on the rich lore of the small village our main character finds himself in.  Each route helps build a more complete picture of just what happened in the past of this town, and no one heroine really takes the center stage like Nene in Sabbat did.

What results from this change in focus is that Senren Banka feels a bit more unfocused than Sabbat, with a story that feels fractured between all the routes--there is no "true" route that pulls all the elements together into a cohesive whole.  Each route ends with valuable context missing for why things happen.  That said, it's ALSO nice that no heroine feels particularly lesser in importance,  Pick a heroine without fear that she's the one that got added in just to check a box off.

That said, Murasame was far and away my favorite of the girls.  10/10 would hand feed again.

68746022.review:
[h1] My perspective on "Senren＊Banka" [/h1]

[h1] Overall: 6.5/10 [/h1]

[Senren＊Banka], in my opinion, has its own place right in the middle of VN spectrum: Not too heavy of a story and not too focused on "special scenes". A leisure read that does not weight down too much on your conscience, but also does not leave that big of a memorable souvenir in your mind either. It could be judged as something 'too average' and 'too cliche', but we all know that sometimes we just want to blast through a feel-good read and enjoy a heartwarming average story. [Senren＊Banka] scratches that of itch pretty well.

[b] Design: 8/10 [/b]

The strongest part. Nothing much to critique about this, as everything is almost how it should be as Yuzusoft's game. There are some problem with proportion on some of the CGs, but to my non-artistic untrained eyes, I do not see that much of errors. The cast are designed very attractively, as well as the sprites and SD sprites, which constitute the standard charm of most modern VNs. 

[b] Story: 5.0/10 [/b]

In my opinion, the weakest aspect of the whole. I have not read many recent VNs lately, but it seems that the one that I did (post 2015) focused too much on each story segments and neglect to seemlessly connects common route to character routes in a seemless, coherent manner. A lot of stuff happens during the common route and the narrative there is quite enjoyable, while most of the characters' arcs were almost too bland and cliche to the point of being almost a filler. I almost felt like I have finished reading the whole story after the common route ends and there was no need to read any further. There are some routes that are exceptions, in which the narrative from the common route continues to be relevant throughout, but most of them hardly ever answer the questions set in the common route. This really kills the urge to replay the VN after finishing everything.

Another disappointing aspect to the story is that everything feels too "optimistic". The situation dealt a god-like hands to our cast almost all the time, and I felt almost no tension from the scenes in which other VNs with tense situation would keep me on edge (I am talking to you, Kara no Shoujo). I felt that the character does not have things 'at stakes' despite the situation portrayed them to do so, and that made the story felt too bland on the serious side despite having serious tone of lore with Japanese mythical curses, gods, and legend.

[spoiler] Story enjoyment: Lena > Murasame >> Mako >>>>>> Yoshino 
- Yes, most of us played the Yoshino arc first, and after finished every arc I was really annoyed by the fact that Yoshino route meagerly, if not least, contributed to the lore of the medium and cursed spirit despite being the priestess route.
- On the other hand, even without a proper elaboration to the curse and the medium, Murasame's arc was the only one who shed light on what eventually happen to Murasame after the end of the curse, while other route completely, or almost completely, forgot about her existence altogether. 
- Lena's arc was the reason I gave story score about 5 (average), as I like the symbolism that played there with "The local problem of a conservative, traditional community solved by a pair of outsiders who turned to be the one who care the most". If only there was a ceremony to enshrine Murasamemaru back like in Murasame's arc, Lena's arc would be almost perfect. [/spoiler]

[b] Character & Development: 6/10 [/b]

This pains me the most as there is a lot of potential here, and at one point it almost able to break through the filter of infamous Japanese tropes. What I like about characters in this VNs is that almost all of them started with their own specific archetypes, but later on show several signs that they have other layers in which they could feel like a legit natural character in non-Japanese media. However, those signs quickly dissipates as the common route reaches climax and became almost non-existent during character arcs. Character's portrayal also tends to fluctuate a lot during the latter part, when they either goes in circle or revert back and forth between their developed and undeveloped part. Which makes me grit my teeth in pain for such a missed opportunity to perfection.

All negatives aside, I actually quite enjoyed the (existed) character growth in most of the routes, and the attempt to make several characters cross their archetype, although not 100% succeeded, was charming and refreshing for me. (like in figurative sense, The Coo-dere does not remain only as one, while the annoying small char does not remain annoying or loud throughout.)   

[spoiler] Character enjoyment: Murasame = Yoshino >> Lena > Mako > The Childhood Friends
- Murasame and Yoshino received most of the chances to break through their old archetype to become a well-round attractive character with a sense of their former self left as little spice. Although I would slightly rate Murasame a bit higher as her character arc has a much more fulfilling and fitting closure to the story aspect. 
- Mako was the one who I felt was the biggest missed opportunity I mentioned above[/spoiler]

[b] Music and Voice acting: 7/10 [/b]

Music: Nothing too fancy, nothing horrible. The most proper term I could say here is "fitting". Everything goes very well with its rural Japanese aspect of the game.

VA: I was prepared to be annoyed by some of the voices judging from the character design, however, everything turned out to be very pleasing. I was actually shocked how different the voice range of Yoshino were portrayed throughout the game, which kind of strange for her character archetype, but all in all, I enjoyed it quite a lot.

Voice enjoyment: Yoshino >>>> Murasame > Mako > Childhood friends > Lena

[b] Extra scenes: 8/10 [/b]

Yes, we all know why we are here, and I can say with confidence that this is has been done well and upto Yuzusoft's standard. 


[b] Summary [/b]

Despite talking a lot about its flaws. I am by no mean saying that I do not enjoy this VN. Minus all the negative parts, it was a very comforting, leisure read with cute character design and good atmosphere. There are AAA quality visual novels out there, but sometimes, you just need something easy-reading, decent VN to pass the time. This is one of the top-quality of such type.
-----------------------------------

Reviewed on: 7 May 2020
HeliumHe

67972260.review:
[b] My Thoughts: [/b] 

8/10

Yuzusoft again delivers a top quality product. A+.  The art is gorgeous with tons of animated facial expressions. Music is catchy and doesn't overstay its welcome. Story is OK, but interesting enough to keep you engaged. Main girls all have unique aspects to them and grow as characters. MC is a cardboard box. Highly recommend for first time VN readers or those looking for a nice Slice of Life story, with some action and a bit of mystery.

Senren Banka has H-scenes. I would recommend going to the official website to download the patch, if it interests you. 


My main criticism is that the story is weak. It has a great setting and sets up a potentially interesting scenario, but doesn't deliver. The common route is generally very good, but it doesn't really go anywhere or expand on its ideas too well. Some of the girls routes are much better than others (although that's normal for many VN's) Masaomi is pretty weak as an MC. I feel like he has no distinct traits besides being a hard-worker and "good guy". I felt no connection with him at all.


Favorite Routes In Order (Spoiler Free):

Lena - Felt like the true ending to me. Would recommend you do this one last, although honestly you can do the routes in any order. Loved the chemistry between these two the most. The story actually felt like it had a point, as it unveiled a lot of the mysteries of the curse. Her quirks were super adorable and I loved her VA. Overall, a very satisfying route.

Yoshino - This was my first route. I really like Yoshino's personality, and how she changed over the course of the story. I feel like some of her arc was a bit contrived and didn't feel natural, but overall I was satisfied with how it ended up. Easily had the best epilogue and "After Story". SO DAMN CUTE. Also had great h-scenes. *wink*

Murasame - I liked Murasame as a character, but she felt more like a little sister or confidant to Masaomi, rather than a lover. (In my opinion!) I just couldn't really get behind their romance. I did find her character to be super interesting and a bit tragic. I will admit the ending was incredibly sweet and it makes me sad she might not be as happy in other routes.

Mako - This was the last route I completed, and also was the weakest. It had the weakest story aspects and was just 130% fluff and diabetes inducing scenes when Mako and Masaomi become a couple. (Not necessarily a bad thing, but it dragged on) The ending felt the least satisfying, as you learn barely anything about the curse. One positive of this route, was that it was hilarious. The dialogue at times had me cracking up more than any other route. 

Roka/Koharu - Extra, shorter routes. Both were cute in their own way. I think Roka deserved her own fully fleshed out route, but oh well. Koharu was forgettable, but Roka at least had an interesting story line. 


I would recommend you play Mako first, and Lena last. Yoshi and Murasame can be fit in however you like. (Same with Roka/Koharu) Although you can really just play it in any order and you'll still enjoy it. The story isn't THAT deep, but I feel like you'll get the most out of it this way.

Thanks for reading. Please support Yuzusoft!

67834149.review:
[quote][h1]Full review (including score): https://youtu.be/CNj6oPM6IOE
Written review below![/h1][/quote]
[h1]The rundown:[/h1]
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Excellent art and music
+ Great mix of fantasy/romance elements
+ Fun and likable characters
+ Cool flowchart feature
+ Plenty of configuration options
[b]Cons:[/b]
- Slow overall pacing
- Character route writing issues

It's finally here. One of my most anticipated visual novels of the year. After the great showing that was Sabbat of the Witch back in 2018, NekoNyan returns to Steam with another Yuzusoft title. Not only did this game commemorate Yuzusoft's 10th anniversary, but it won numerous awards on the year of its release in Japan. As such, I was very excited to finally get to play it in English.

[i]Note: Had to trim review to fit Steam's character limit, check video for full version![/i]

[h2]Pros:[/h2]
[list][*][b]Excellent art and music.[/b] Not only does the game run natively at 1080p (which is already rare for a visual novel), but it does so with some excellent character designs, high-quality CGs, and plenty of movement. In fact, it's not unusual for a character to go through three or four different facial expressions and/or poses when delivering just a single line. Couple that with the detailed character designs and CGs that perfectly match the game's traditional Japanese setting and you have quite the visual experience.

This extends into the game's audio, with Senren＊Banka offering up both some nice voice acting and some really good background music. I wasn't impressed with the music in Sabbat of the Witch, so I honestly wasn't expecting the music here to be as good as it is. There's quite the assortment too, including slower piano tracks for the romantic scenes, high-energy electronic tracks for the game's action scenes, and a bunch of tracks using traditional Japanese instruments to match the game's setting. In fact, I'd say about half of the game's music features the shamisen or koto in some form. It makes for a very nice overall soundtrack and the best I've seen from Yuzusoft thus far.

[*][b]Great mix of fantasy/romance elements.[/b] Despite how it looks, Senren＊Banka is actually more of a fantasy story than it is a romance story. It takes place in this rural Japanese town cut off from most of society, features themes from Japanese mythology, and has both a priestess character and a sentient sword character (both with their own respective routes). It's a fantasy-heavy VN, but yet it manages to actually pull off some decent romance regardless.

Unlike in Sabbat of the Witch, where the fantasy elements felt like an afterthought to the romance, Senren＊Banka manages to find a really nice balance there. The romance gets enough focus that it still progresses in a reasonable manner, yet leaves room for the main story to fully develop. And that main story isn't even that bad. Sure, it's nothing special, but it never grows too ambitious for its own good and doesn't overstay its welcome, making for a really good vessel for the romance bits.

[*][b]Fun and likable characters.[/b] Here we have a cast of heroines that are not only decently developed writing-wise, but are quirky enough in their own right that it's kinda hard not to like them. You've got the shrine maiden who has a problem with cat ears that keep appearing on her head, a kunoichi who has sworn to protect said shrine maiden, a sentient sword spirit that is accidentally summoned by the game's protagonist, and a blonde exchange student that seems to only know how to speak old Japanese. 

None of these characters felt like they were introduced just to fill a specific trope, but rather felt like natural additions to the overall story. They each have some backstory related to the main narrative that you'll find out through their respective routes, routes that also develop said characters at the same time. They're fun to interact with and really carry the experience through the game's writing problems.

[*][b]Cool flowchart feature.[/b] At any time during play, you can open said flowchart and see which choices led you where and which scenes you have and/or haven't read. This makes it incredibly easy to get on the route you want and also eliminates the need for any sort of guide. (trimmed)

[*][b]Plenty of configuration options.[/b] Senren＊Banka really goes above and beyond what I would normally expect from a VN, setting the example for others to follow. (trimmed)[/list]

[h2]Cons:[/h2]
[list][*][b]Slow overall pacing.[/b] The main problem I have with Senren＊Banka's writing is just how slow it is. This is not one of those VNs where the common route is slow and the character routes pick up pace later nor one of those VNs with constantly shifting pacing. Senren＊Banka is just slow 100% of the time. Whether you're in the common route or in one of the game's many character routes, the pacing just never really changes. Don't get me wrong, I think a VN with slow pacing can be great, especially so because most VNs suffer from writing issues caused by erratic pacing, but in Senren＊Banka's case, it just makes everything feel dragged out.

This is a VN that stretches its story to the absolute limit, dragging out story scenes, giving overly wordy descriptions, and adding in a bunch of filler along the way. A story event that can maybe take half a day to resolve somehow takes several days to do so, with Murasame's route being the worst offender here. The characters carry the story to an extent, but it becomes very hard not to notice just how slow everything is, especially once you get into the character routes where major story developments usually happen. It really brings down the reading experience, making it difficult to read for more than a couple hours at a time.

[*][b]Character route writing issues.[/b] The pacing issue may be prevalent throughout the entire game, but the character routes have some additional issues exclusive to them. And unfortunately, these issues are the result of the game's H-scenes. In fact, these scenes are a large part of why the pacing felt so slow in the character routes. That is because, once the romance has been developed enough, the character routes devolve into a series of filler scenes to pad out the game's H-scenes. You'll go from H-scene to a day full of filler and maybe a small story development back to another H-scene and so on.

What makes it worse is that it is 100% noticeable that these filler scenes are just there to serve the H-scenes, as the protagonist and heroine will often discuss when the next time they can do it is or what they'll do during it. Yoshino and Mako's routes are the main offenders there. It's like the writers knew they had to include the H-scenes somewhere, but spent so much time developing the story and characters elsewhere that they were forced to dump them all at the end of each character route and hand over the reigns to a teenager to write. Again, I don't have any problem with such scenes being included, but when it leads to issues like this, it does bring down the experience a bit. Fortunately, it's only around the last third of each character route that suffers from this, but its still an issue regardless.[/list]

[h2]Overall:[/h2]
Although not quite as good as Yuzusoft's last English release, Sabbat of the Witch, Senren＊Banka is still a good visual novel all things considered. The mix of fantasy and romance is done well, the art and music are top-notch, the flowchart feature is cool, and the characters are interesting enough that they carry the experience through the game's writing problems. The slow pacing and filler scenes do make the game hard to play for longer sessions, but it's a fun enough experience to play though in smaller chunks.

Follow my [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/3215371]Steam Curator Page[/url][/b] for more reviews + videos!

66195906.review:
Admittedly, I've always been a huge fan of the history genre since the girls always wear super adorable clothes during that era. However, technically Senren＊Banka does not play in this era but the village our protagonist visits just happens to somehow be stuck in the past. Therefore, I suspected this game to be a little bit different than the usual games I'm used to that rather played either in modern times or well.. in the past. If I had to describe my appeal to this genre, I would say it mostly is because the female characters often do have a strong personality, especially since they grew up with constant danger around them.

Senren＊Banka opens with Masaomi visiting the village Hoori. You see, his grandfather lives here and thus, he has memories of spending his childhood here as well. This village is quite special since it seems to be stuck in the past. During his time there, he tries to draw a blade, that is stuck in a stone, as a lot of people tried to achieve this - without any success. However, it happens that Masaomi breaks this blade in half and while being totally shocked, he starts to get aware of Murasame, the caretaker of the divine blade, who luckily manages to restore it. To make it worse, he has to take responsibility for his actions now and gets involved in an arranged marriage with the village's shrine maiden.

As aforementioned, I found the technically mixed genres very appealing since I often happened to be unsure what genre I want to play. I'm sure it's relatable that sometimes one is in the mood for something light-hearted whilst other times some action would be a nice change of scenario as well. However, despite containing the modern and past era, it hardly feels like it does actually play in the modern time besides Masaomi being a little bit surprised in the beginning, yet he just accepted it pretty soon and it wasn't really any different than the usual history games I've played before although I would say it's less gory. Sometimes, Senren＊Banka makes use of the merge and uses modern clothes for casual occasions or when the characters are in school.

Of course, the action isn't missing here as well, which is one of the most interesting parts of this game. Unfortunately, there is a curse lingering here in the family of the fiancé of our protagonist and she has to purify evil beings. This confirms my suspect above with the strong female characters, as she usually fights them off with her childhood friend and bodyguard. Actually, I found that all the female characters were independent and adorable, to top it off. I really appreciate it when a girl isn't helpless and has to get protected by the guy simply because she is female, but in Senren＊Banka Masaomi and his fiancé are fighting the spirits off together, which is a nice resolution as he still takes care of her and honestly, it's a lot more romantic to work together.

Talking about romantic, I am an ultimate fan of arranged marriages. It's like Masaomi forced to marry someone and therefore, it's evident that he will spend a lot of time with his fiancé. The thing I like about this relationship is that it resembles a hate-and-love relationship. And for unknown reasons, the shrine maiden really does not like him, well in the beginning at least. However, it was heartwarming to see her slowly opening up to him and with this, her behavior started to change as well. After all, there is a secretive reason why she doesn't have any friends besides her bodyguard, but that's fine too since their relationship is just adorable and one can easily tell they're very close despite their different personalities.

Now, the disappointing thing here is that there is basically zero romance available in the common route although the arranged marriage was such a promising premise. I felt rather like the common route focused entirely on telling the story and after it's done, the romance starts to bloom. Initially, I wouldn't mind this concept as well, yet, it was such a shame that both genres didn't get merged within the common route. It rather feels like I went through an action story-driven visual novel at first and then ended up with a slice-of-life dating sim the other half of the game and honestly, it would have been much more interesting if both elements would have been present at the same time.

In total, there are four main romance routes available and two sub-routes that unlock after going through at least one route. Although the choices do alter a few events, there are very little and mostly determine with which heroine the player is going to get together. That being said, there are a lot of interesting features here that I didn't often see in visual novels such as the flow chart where the player can choose different choices but doesn't have to skip through the whole game, plus the system is more visible this way. On a piece of side information, there is also a skip text button, as well as skip to previous and next choices and events. I occurred a few crashes right when the game jumped to the next chapter so that wasn't a problem when I launched it again because I could skip right to the part immediately.

Graphic-wise, one can immediately tell that Senren＊Banka is a high-quality visual novel. Besides the usual sprites, there are cute chibi drawings available as well which greatly spiced up the happenings. A thing I noticed right away was that the sprites have multiple facials expressions, poses and a lot of different clothes plus hairstyles available depending on the impressive scene, to say the least. The variety of the sprites greatly helped with the immersion and along with that the top-notch voice-over. For this aspect, there is a new feature implemented as well: A bar where you can see when the voice over is going to be done. This was often an issue for me since I cannot understand Japanese and therefore, never knew whether the characters were done talking or just leaving some room for a dramatic pause.

Senren＊Banka is a gorgeous visual novel that includes adorable girls with a supernatural theme. Whilst I found it was a shame that the romance and action plot didn't get fused until the common route was over, I still liked each girl and it was tough to decide which girl to pursue first. Regardless, I enjoyed that this game was a nice change to the usual dating sims I've played before since the common route isn't all about slice-of-life but offers an actual story with some action that made me curious about all the mysteries that came along with the supernatural aspect. That being said, Senren＊Banka is an adorable visual novel with strong female characters to romance fueled with a mystery that is just waiting to get unfolded.

66149424.review:
Senren*Banka is an excellent romance/slice of life VN that sprinkles in a bit of drama and mystery along with a lovable cast to create a heartwarming experience. The writing, art, and extras hit all the right notes, and the game has no major flaws. It's an easy recommend to anyone who enjoys VNs.

The game starts off in the common route, where the protagonist, Masaomi, has returned to the quaint village of Hoori where he grew up. The common route serves to introduce the heroines, and does this better for some than others, but also is a compelling story in its own right.  I thoroughly enjoyed reading it, and in no way felt like I was treading water until the real action of the heroines' routes began.

Afterward, the game branches off into routes for the different heroines that offer some nice variety, with some focusing more on lighthearted comedy and slice of life and others more on emotional drama and Hoori's supernatural mysteries. Of course, this means that depending on your tastes you will likely enjoy some more than others (my favorite was Murasame's,) but I found all the routes enjoyable. Even in the more serious routes though, Senren*Banka still makes time for jokes (which mostly land) and showing the little interactions between the characters that breathe life into their relationships. It also helps that all the heroines are quite likeable and written with believable and compelling motivations and challenges.

Senren*Banka also offers top notch production values and QoL features. The art looks great, with characters constantly exhibiting subtle changes of expression during their lines, and the use of traditional music and instruments compliments the aesthetic of Hoori. On the QoL side, the game offers a flowchart that maps out decisions and routes, and it's so convenient I wish more VN's had this feature. No more saving in 10 different slots and trying to remember which one goes with which route. There's also a free 18+ patch easily available from the developer's website for those who are interested, though I think the game is worth playing either way. 

Again, if you enjoy VNs, I think there's little reason not to play Senren*Banka. The story is fun, the game looks great, and all the features make is easy to play.
